metadata.document_title: "Building Community Resilience through Regenerative Farming and Education"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does The Patch Organics aim to increase community resilience through regenerative farming and education?
2. What specific programs and projects does The Patch Organics offer to achieve their mission?
3. In what ways is The Patch Organics working towards sustainability and renewable energy in their farming operations?

__data__.text:
We are a permaculture-designed and family-run business that runs educational workshops and grows organic pasture-raised chickens and biodynamic veggies. We share-farm on a large certified organic farm in Bellingen, NSW. Our mission is to increase community resilience through education, regenerated land and increased health.We run the following programs:
- Permaculture Design Course
- Introduction to Hunting
- Market Gardening Course
We are working on the following projects:
- Zero waste chicken - how to create a circular economy and re-value food waste through partnership
- Bellingen Biodynamic Eggs - Introducing a certified organic and biodynamic egg enterprise
- Off-grid farming - Transitioning to 100% renewable energy for our on-farm operations
- Doubling production of organic chicken - scaling up our chicken enterprise to double production['Regenerative Practices', 'Ecological Practices (certifications)']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/thepatchorganics', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/thepatchorganics', 'Email': 'mailto:thepatch.bellingen@gmail.com', 'Website': 'https://www.thepatchorganics.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Golden Hill Farm: A Comprehensive Guide to Ethical Poultry Farming and Regenerative Practices from Paddock to Plate"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How did the owners of Golden Hill Farm transition from mixed farming ventures to focusing on regeneratively farming meat chickens?
2. What challenges did Golden Hill Farm face in terms of processing their ethically raised poultry, and how are they working to overcome these challenges?
3. How does Golden Hill Farm plan to share their knowledge and produce with their community, and what steps are they taking to establish an onsite poultry processing facility and distribution business?

__data__.text:
We are Luke, De’arne, Koa and Finn and we arrived at Golden Hill Farm in September 2021 as optimistic farmers with big dreams. We arrived at our farm (sight unseen) located between Bundaberg and Seventeen-Seventy on Gooreng Gooreng country. Our farm was not looking healthy, having been neglected and subject to drought for the past several years. But we could see our land's potential. As custodians of our land, we set out to establish regenerative, sustainable and ethical farming techniques.
With limited hands-on experience but big intentions and dreams, we experimented with mixed farming ventures, and it didn't take long for us to realise we had bitten off more than we could chew. We quickly reassessed, listened to our community, and realised that farming meat chickens was where our hearts were aligned. Regeneratively farming meat chickens improves our soil health and rejuvenates our pastures whilst supplying our family and community with ethically raised and nutrient-dense poultry.Continue learning how to increase the nutrient density of our chickens.
Continue implementing best-practice farming methods to improve soil health.
Share our produce and knowledge with our community.
Establish an onsite poultry processing facility and distribution business.
After raising meat chickens, processing them on farm and running workshops, we quickly realised that our community wanted to support our vision to grow and process chickens ethically on pasture, offering our region paddock to plate poultry. Unfortunately, the closest abattoir is three and a half hours from our farm, which does not align with our intention to produce and process ethical poultry. We are in the process of establishing an onsite processing facility that will allow us to grow, learn and share.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://instagram.com/goldenhill_farm/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100077333497386', 'Email': 'mailto:info@goldenhillfarm.com.au', 'Website':

metadata.document_title: "Synergistic Approaches to Sustainable Agriculture: Regenerative Farming Practices and Biodiversity Conservation in North Victoria"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has J and S Bate's farming practices evolved over the past four years in north Victoria near Avenel?
2. What specific strategies have J and S Bate implemented to improve soil health on their 900-acre farm in north Victoria?
3. What conservation efforts have J and S Bate undertaken on their farm to increase biodiversity, and what challenges have they faced in implementing these efforts?

__data__.text:
We farm on 900 acres in north Victoria, near Avenel. We run Merino ewes for wool and White Suffolk rams for lambs. Four years ago, we began to question how we were farming and subsequently stopped using most inputs and chemicals and started our journey to improve soil health.
We are improving soil health through grazing management, adding more paddocks, running animals in 1-2 mobs (except during lambing), and the use of cover crops in summer and winter. We have also undertaken tree/native understorey planting to increase biodiversity on our farm, which includes fencing off paddock trees to protect them.We received a Landcare grant to fence off a seasonal creek several years ago. The creek now has thick native vegetation throughout.
We also received funding for a grey box grassy woodland corridor two years ago. We maintain both these sites as best we can.
We would like to fence off our dams to restore habitat but haven't tackled this yet as it is an expensive project.['Regenerative Practices']{'Email': 'mailto:benacre49@gmail.com'}

__data__.text:
We grow food for our health, your health and Earth's.
We use regenerative practices, no synthetic sprays, bugs to eat bugs and lots of love and care to grow nutritious mixed-leaf salad mixes for our local community.We are currently prepping more garden beds for our first big season starting Feb 2024. This includes creating a nursery space for our microgreens and seedlings and a wonderful wash and pack area. Due to the sweltering heat, we're hoping Santa brings us a refrigerated van for harvest storage and delivery, perhaps in the form of an affordable 2nd hand version.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/folksmallfarm/', 'Email': 'mailto:kathrynmaya@gmail.com'}

metadata.document_title: "Growing Green: The Journey of Stormflower Vineyard Towards Organic Certification, Sustainable Practices, and Future Goals in Margaret River"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Stormflower Vineyard's focus on sustainable farming practices, such as improving soil health and using organic products, contributed to the quality of their wines?
2. What changes has Stormflower Vineyard implemented in order to make their vineyard more resilient to extreme weather and disease since purchasing it in 2007?
3. How has Stormflower Vineyard's transition to becoming a certified organic wine producer in 2016 impacted their business operations and overall philosophy?

__data__.text:
Stormflower is a small certified organic wine producer in the Wilyabrup pocket of the Margaret River wine region. Stormflower is owned and operated by David Martin, one of the founders of Little Creatures Brewery in Fremantle, the Alex Hotel in Perth and Weelhamby Farm in Perenjori. David bought the vineyard in June 2007 with two friends and bought out his partners in 2014. With David’s daughter Alex and son in law Tim now living locally and both involved in Stormflower, it is becoming more deeply rooted as a small family business.
The aim of Stormflower is to create a wine business that is small, single vineyard and produces wine of the highest quality but does not take itself too seriously. Being located in Wilyabrup among some world class wineries it is important to produce great quality Cabernet Sauvignon and Chardonnay, and that is a constant focus of our team. All wines are made only with fruit from our vineyard.
Sustainable farming is an integral part of the Stormflower philosophy. We pay great attention to the health of the soil, and this results in a vineyard that is a healthy, biodiverse and resilient system. The vineyard has gone through many changes since we bought it in 2007. We have been working hard to make the vineyard more resilient to extreme weather and disease by focusing on the health of the soil and consequently the vines. We began our organic journey more than 10 years ago and over this time the use of humates, fish emulsion, seaweed products and molasses has improved the native soil microbiology and contributed to soil health and the growing of better cover crops which protect the surface of the soil. To these simple organic practices, we have more recently focused on basic management of soil pH and nutrition, particularly organic phosphates, which has created a snowballing effect of good health in the vineyard. Stormflower achieved full organic certification in November 2016.Stormflower is a member of both the

metadata.document_title: Indigenous-Owned Bush Tukka and Bush Medicine Consultancy: Promoting Cultural Connection and Sustainable Business Practices
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How is Tribal Voice Connections promoting cultural connection and sustainable business practices through their Indigenous-owned Bush Tukka and Bush Medicine consultancy business?
2. What specific grassroots business projects is Tribal Voice Connections currently working on, and how do they aim to inspire other remote communities?
3. In what ways does Tribal Voice Connections plan to engage with the local community and provide employment and training opportunities for First Nations peoples through their Caring for Country program and native plant land regeneration program?

__data__.text:
Tribal Voice Connections is 100% Indigenous owned and run Bush Tukka and Bush Medicine consultancy business. We provide Cultural consultancy including health and wellbeing presentations and country and cooking connections to anyone interested in connection to our cultural roots.
We are on a mission to create a native plant, bush foods and bush medicine business model to inspire other remote communities.
We are currently working to create a native bush tukka market garden on Eastern Yalanji Country that will supply native bush foods to local businesses in Cairns, Mossman and Port Douglas. As part of our Caring for Country program, we also plan to develop a native plant land regeneration program for the Mt Carbine Tungsten mine to provide employment and training opportunities for the bama (First Nations) traditional peoples.Grassroots business projects:
Seek funding for the market garden on Eastern Yalanji Country, including equipment and assets such as water tanks, water pumps and an irrigation system.
Engage a horticulturist to assess our land and soil.
Develop a seed-collecting program to employ local First Nations peoples.
Develop an educational Cultural eco camping on Country program to offer schools and the public the opportunity to learn about native bush foods and medicines.['Regenerative Practices']{'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/tribalvoiceconnections/', 'Email': 'mailto:bushtukkainfo@gmail.com'}

__data__.text:
Old Man Creek is an Angus cattle Stud located at Sandigo, in the Riverina region of New South Wales. The Stud was created in 2016 from the purchase of 120 Stud Angus cattle from various cattle studs. It is owned and operated by Michael and Heloise Gooden.
Our aim is to breed animals that have been raised on grass in a cell grazing operation all their lives. We run a regenerative grazing business, based on Holistic Management principles. If you have similar land management goals, and breeding objectives, then you should consider our animals.We are currently working on the prospect of a direct-to-market option for selling our cull bulls for meat.['Ecological Outcomes Verified (EOV)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/oldmancreek/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/OldManCreek/', 'Email': 'mailto:mjgooden@oldmancreek.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.oldmancreek.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: Sustainable Walnut Farming at Coaldale Walnuts: Regenerative Practices, High-Quality Products, and Family Tradition
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Coaldale Walnuts practice regenerative farming principles to enhance the integrity and biodiversity of their soils?
2. What varieties of walnuts does Coaldale Walnuts grow in the deep alluvial soils on the banks of the Coal River?
3. How does Coaldale Walnuts reduce their carbon footprint and promote biodiversity on their property through revegetation and sustainable practices?

metadata.EGS Provider: Old Man Creek Grass Fed Bulls

__data__.text:
Coaldale Walnuts is a walnut farm in the Coal Valley, near Richmond in Tasmania. We produce the tastiest walnuts and pickled walnuts you'll ever try! We grow Chandler and Franquette varieties in the deep alluvial soils on the banks of the Coal River.
We embrace regenerative farming principles, using mainly organic fertilisers and management practices that enhance the integrity and biodiversity of our soils. We recycle all orchard waste so that organic matter goes back into the orchard system, and we use sheep to graze the orchard to improve nutrient cycling and reduce fossil fuel use.
We are a multigenerational family business proud to produce a high-quality health product, feeding other families across Tasmania and Australia.Reducing unsustainable packaging and other business consumables
Revegetating areas of the property to improve biodiversity and reduce carbon footprint['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://instagram.com/coaldalewalnuts', 'Facebook': 'https://facebook.com/coaldalewalnut', 'Email': 'mailto:info@coaldalewalnuts.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.coaldalewalnuts.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Plump Berries: A Guide to Regenerative Farming Practices for Sustainable Agriculture and Handcrafted Spirits"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Plump Berries practice regenerative farming to heal the soil and rebalance the ecosystem on their farm?
2. What specific strategies does Plump Berries employ to produce high quality, nutrient-dense berries, fruits, fruit spirits, and wines for local consumption?
3. How has the ecosystem on Plump Berries' farm improved since they started implementing regenerative farming practices, such as no chemical use, organic composts, and diversification of companion plants?

__data__.text:
Plump Berries is a berry farm and distillery set on a 10-acre property operated by Olivia and Aaron. We grow, pick, make, and package ourselves. Our fruit wines, spirits and liqueurs are unique handcrafted, single-origin, small-batch products created in our nano-distillery.
We take a soil-first approach to growing and are committed to healing the soil and rebalancing the ecosystem on our farm. We do not use any herbicides, fungicides or pesticides on or near our crops, nor do we use synthetic fertilisers. We foster diversity in our patches by growing a variety of crops together, and companion planting. We feed the soil locally sourced organic matter, and fertigate our crops with compost, kelp and fish waste teas. Every decision we make is guided by our commitment to soil health, natural growing, nutrient-dense food, utilising what we have, and planning for continuous improvement.Plump Berries’ key project is producing high quality, nutrient dense berries, fruits, fruit spirits and wines, primarily for local consumption. Our key regenerative project is managing the recovery of the ecosystem following conventional farming practices. We arrived on the farm in April 2022. Our soil restoration strategy started with no chemical use, the addition of organic composts, mulches and fertigation sprays, and diversification of companion plants, to rebuild soil structure and biology. Soil testing in early 2023 reinforced the ongoing strategies and guided new ones. The diversity of insect and arachnid life increased noticeably in the first berry season, by enabling nature to heal the ecosystem. We are continuing with these strategies and also planning more to further increase diversity and improve soil health. In keeping with regenerative principles, we are also planning towards greater use of livestock on the farm and improving the health of the waterway.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/plump_berries/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/plumpberriesfarm', 'Email':

metadata.document_title: "Revolutionizing Agriculture: A Comprehensive Guide to Biodynamic Dairy Farming and Regenerative Practices"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Mungalli Creek Dairy differentiate itself from other dairy farming operations in Australia?
2. What certifications does Mungalli Creek Dairy hold for their dairy products and farming practices?
3. What steps is Mungalli Creek Dairy taking to reduce their environmental footprint and promote regenerative farming practices?

__data__.text:
Mungalli Creek Dairy is a paddock to plate dairy farming operation, producing premium Biodynamic Dairy products.
As well as our own 3 farms we purchase milk from an additional 5 farming operations. The milk from our farm and 2 other farms is certified Demeter Biodynamic with the Biodynamic Research Institute. As well as producing milk, we also process this into a range of certified products including packaged milk, yoghurt, cheese, cream and ice cream. These products are sold predominantly in North Queensland but also throughout the East Coast in organic and specialty stores.
We are the only family-owned Biodynamic Dairy processor in Australia and we aim to lead the way in earth repair and regenerative farming whilst producing the highest quality products.Biodynamic Farming across three farms - ensuring healthy soil and animals
Producing premium dairy products with care and minimal processing
Upgrading our ice cream manufacturing to handle greater capacity
Monitor how to reduce our environmental footprint
Providing educational activities and programs['Regenerative Practices', 'Ecological Practices (certifications)']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/mungallicreek', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/mungallicreek/', 'Email': 'mailto:rob@mungallicreekdairy.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.mungallicreekdairy.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Goodies Farm: A Family-Owned Regenerative Farming and Local Food Hub in Western Australia - A Comprehensive Overview"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Goodies Farm in Western Australia transitioned to alternative farming methods over the past few years, and what specific changes have they made to improve soil health and reduce artificial inputs?
2. What are the key components of the Local Goodies Food hub being built by Goodies Farm in Denmark, WA, and how will it support the local community and promote sustainable food practices?
3. Can Goodies Farm provide insights into their experience with regenerative farming practices, including their progress, challenges faced, and future plans for improving soil health and crop production?

__data__.text:
Goodies Farm is a family-owned and operated mixed broadacre farm based in Kendenup, Western Australia. We are on a mission to improve soil health whilst providing food for our local community.
Our property is 800 hectares, 500 of which are arable or suitable for cropping. We grow a diverse range of cereals and legumes using biological farming methods.
We have been farming for 25 years and started transitioning to alternative farming methods in 2018. We immediately removed fungicide and insecticide and have slowly reduced our artificial fertiliser usage. We still use a minimal amount of herbicide that we buffer with citric acid and fulvic acid as a knockdown spray before we sow our crops, but we continue to look for alternative methods.
2022 was our first year farming without artificial inputs. We now use vermicast, guano, compost and mineral sprays to improve soil health and feed our crops. We will create our own bio fertiliser in the upcoming season and continue to try different crops and varieties.
We are now five years into our regenerative journey and are improving our practices and soil health every day.We are currently building a Local Goodies Food hub in Denmark, WA. The Shed will house a commercial kitchen, cool room, pantry room, flour milling and packing room, workshop space, toilet and shower and be surrounded by food growing opportunities and market gardens.
We have also recently completed part one of a Tree Planting Carbon Project with Wide Open Agriculture & Dirty Clean Food.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/goodiesfarm/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/goodiesfarmwa', 'Email': 'mailto:pen@goodiesfarm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.goodiesfarm.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: Yimby Compost: Empowering Youth to Upcycle Nutrients and Combat Climate Change through Community-Based Waste Collection and Nutrient Cycling Initiative
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How many households does Yimby Compost currently service on a weekly basis?
2. What is the goal for the number of households Yimby Compost aims to scale up to by 2030?
3. How does Yimby Compost involve young people aged 18-30 in their initiative through the YIMBY GYMby program?

__data__.text:
Yimby Compost is a distributed community-based compost initiative and waste collection service in Castlemaine.

We train a community of volunteer composters who collect kitchen scraps from households in their neighbourhood and compost them in their backyards with the YIMBY method. We add locally sourced carbon-rich materials to ensure the compost is good quality and meets EPA standards for use in a food production garden.

Instead of food scraps going to waste, they’re returned as nutrient dense compost to our soil. That’s the circular economy at work!
YIMBY is an alternative to the large scale FOGO industrial system that collects food scraps, aggregates in large volumes, and produces a low quality ‘mulch’.
Yimby Compost is also about collaboration and building the system from the ground up. We have regular composter gatherings where we learn from each other, check in, provide updates and share a meal.

Yimby Compost is underpinned by a desire for a truly local system that builds community whilst cycling nutrients and regenerating local soils.YIMBY compost is currently servicing over 200 households weekly, with our 17 composters collectively processing 500 kgs of food scraps each week. We are working on scaling up to 8000 households by 2030, supporting over 200 composters. YIMBY aims to be an alternative to the industrial scale management of food waste, that inadvertently downgrades nutrients, removing them from the cycle of life.YIMBY provides intensive training and support for our composters, as well as providing information and training for the general public, to increase the skills and knowledge in our community and make high quality compost, upcycling nutrients.YIMBY GYMby is an initiative that involves young people 18-30 on a casual basis to help our dedicated composters to do the heavy work of turning a tonne of compost every 6 weeks. Our GYMby volunteers are motivated to contribute to our system because it is an antidote to powerlessness in the face of

metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Yimby Compost empower youth in Brisbane, Australia to combat climate change through community-based waste collection and nutrient cycling initiatives?
2. What specific training and support does Yimby Compost provide to its composters and the general public to increase skills and knowledge in the community and produce high-quality compost?
3. How does Yimby Compost's GYMby initiative engage young people aged 18-30 in the process of upcycling nutrients and contributing to the fight against climate change, while also providing them with a sense of empowerment and community involvement?

__data__.text: waste, that inadvertently downgrades nutrients, removing them from the cycle of life.YIMBY provides intensive training and support for our composters, as well as providing information and training for the general public, to increase the skills and knowledge in our community and make high quality compost, upcycling nutrients.YIMBY GYMby is an initiative that involves young people 18-30 on a casual basis to help our dedicated composters to do the heavy work of turning a tonne of compost every 6 weeks. Our GYMby volunteers are motivated to contribute to our system because it is an antidote to powerlessness in the face of climate change; they feel good, get to hang out with peers, and get active. metadata.document_title: "Amber Creek Farm: A Holistic Approach to Regenerative Farming, Local Collaboration, and Sustainable Practices"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Amber Creek Farm combine farming and sawmilling to create a positive impact on the environment and local community?
2. What specific regenerative practices does Amber Creek Farm implement to improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and sequester carbon?
3. In what ways does Amber Creek Farm engage with the local community and support local businesses through their operations and initiatives?

__data__.text:
Amber Creek Farm is located at Fish Creek in South Gippsland, on the doorstep to Wilson’s Promontory. The farm is set on 400 acres of rolling countryside and two enterprises are run by the Bright Family from the property: Hogs & Logs.
Amber Creek is our home, our work, our life and our lessons. It’s where we are raising children and animals and building businesses and community.
From varied backgrounds in the health field, trades and generational farming, we are using this knowledge to forge our own pathway by combining two seemingly unrelated industries (farming and sawmilling) to build carbon, regenerate the soil and increase biodiversity.
Positive impact: creating fertile soil, sequestering carbon, creating habitat, generating local economic activity and engaging with the local community.
No waste: regarding everything as a resource.
Regenerative: using the pigs normally destructive habits of digging with their faces to create compost and build soil health and volume.
Local: trading with local businesses. Developing a regionally distinct product.Fit out of new packing and storage room for meat
Rebuild shelters and feed pads for pigs
Building relationships with agroforestry growers and assisting with harvest/firewood connections
Completing the final infrastructure at the newly built mill (retail shed/office and moulder all weather annexe)
Explore agri-tourism with bush tracks/walk and on farm accomodation['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/ambercreekfarm/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/ambercreekfarm', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@ambercreekfarm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://ambercreekfarm.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Jillamatong: A Comprehensive Guide to Regenerative Agriculture, Biodiversity Restoration, and Sustainable Land Management"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Jillamatong in Braidwood, Australia, demonstrate regenerative agricultural practices and sustainable land management?
2. What specific projects and activities are undertaken at Jillamatong to promote biodiversity restoration and ecological sustainability?
3. In what ways do cattle play a crucial role in improving soil and landscape function at Jillamatong, and how are regenerative practices implemented to enhance biodiversity and soil carbon levels on the farm?

__data__.text:
Jillamatong is a third-generation family farm located in the town of Braidwood in the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales. We aim to understand regenerative agricultural practices, implement what works for us and showcase what doesn't. We have built Jillamatong into a positive ecological, social and financial environment — a model demonstrating how to repair a damaged landscape with regenerative practices.


The insects and birds love it, too.There are always tree-planting and nurturing projects happening
Native grass harvesting in season
Truffles, yabbies, and garlic harvesting
Cattle are the main tool for improving soil and landscape function
We spread multi-species with our own biological preparations to speed up the development of biodiversity and soil carbon['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/jillamatong/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/p/Jillamatong-100063562838903/', 'Email': 'mailto:mr.royds@icloud.com', 'Website': 'https://soilsforlife.org.au/the-jillamatong-story/'}

metadata.document_title: "Revolutionizing Agriculture: Empowering Farmers with Regenerative Practices for Soil Health and Sustainability"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Soil Land Food support farmers and rural communities in building capacity for regenerative agriculture and sustainable practices?
2. What specific projects and programs does Soil Land Food offer to help assess and improve soil health, and how are these initiatives benefiting Australian landcare groups and farmers?
3. In what ways does Soil Land Food contribute to the empowerment of farmers through their learning programs on regenerative agriculture, soil health, and sustainable farming practices?

__data__.text:
Soil Land Food is a small consultancy specialising in ecological and regenerative agriculture, soils, rural landscapes, food systems, agroecology, rural extension and capacity building. We help farmers and rural communities build their capacity to create positive futures that support the planet while building local rural economies, healthy rural landscapes and healthy communities.HASH - Holistic Assessment of Soil Health Project
In this project, we are developing a holistic set of indicators to assess and monitor soil health. It builds on the RASH (Rapid Assessment of Soil Health) that we developed and that is used across Australia by landcare groups and farmers to assess and monitor soil health.
Soil Land Food's Learning Programs
We run a wide range of workshops, bootcamps and courses on regenerative agriculture topics including the following:
Planning your farm landscape
Digging Deeper into Soils
Reboot your soil
Making Biofertilisers on farm
Making Compost on farm['Funded by Sustainable Table', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/soillandfood/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/soillandfood', 'Email': 'mailto:enquiries@soillandfood.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.soillandfood.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Echo Valley Farm: Ethical, Sustainable, Regenerative Farming Practices and Community Support with On-Farm Meathouse"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How did Echo Valley Farm develop their '4 Good' principles and how do they apply them to their farming operations?
2. What initiatives has Echo Valley Farm undertaken to establish an on-farm boning and packing facility, the 4Goods Meathouse, and how have they involved their community in this project?
3. In what ways does Echo Valley Farm aim to share their story, learnings, opportunities, and regenerative practices with the public through the establishment of a commercial kitchen, workshop, and education venue on their farm?

__data__.text:
We are Randal, Juanita, Eli and Bridey Breen and we run Echo Valley Farm – a 600 acre venture spread across 2 farms in Bundjalung Country in the Nation of the Githabul people, Goomburra Valley, Southeast Queensland.
Since our farming adventure began, we have developed, and continue to develop, a multi species integrated farming system that includes a range of enterprises such as grass fed and finished beef, pastured poultry, pastured pigs, multi-species cover cropping, and opportunistic seasonal small cropping.
Ethical, sustainable, regenerative and holistic farming. What does it mean to us?
When establishing our farming operation at Echo Valley, sound and ethical ecological farming practices took priority. Thinking long on how we could integrate these approaches into our farm systems, we developed the ‘4 Good’ principles.
‘Good for the animal, good for the land, good for the farmer and good for you’.
These 4 values are integral to every industry on farm, with each farming enterprise at Echo Valley having been thoughtfully established to be in harmony and linked to the other on-farm systems, creating a farm that not only applies the 4 goods, but is holistic in its approach.For the last 2 years we have been working towards establishing an on-farm boning and packing facility, our 4Goods Meathouse.
In August of this year our vision became a reality, and with the support of our community and a crowdfunding campaign, we get our facility up and running!
We are working towards establishing a commercial kitchen to work in partnership with the Meathouse, along with a workshop and education venue, to enable us to share the story, learnings, opportunities, and regenerative practices of all that we do at Echo Valley.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/echovalleyfarmer/', 'Facebook':

metadata.document_title: "Beermullah Farm: Regenerative Farming, Sustainability, Diversification, Direct Sales, and Community Engagement"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Beermullah Beef implemented regenerative farming practices on their Red Angus Beef farm in Beermullah, Australia, and what specific methods have they used to regenerate wetlands and biodiversity on their property?
2. In what ways has Beermullah Beef engaged with the community and promoted sustainability through initiatives such as founding the Evergreen grower group and offering farm accommodation in the Beermullah Shearing Shed?
3. How has Beermullah Beef diversified their operations and expanded their customer base through direct sales of their beef, workshops for wheatbelt farmers, and field day visits for fellow farmers and city customers?

__data__.text:
Beermullah Beef is a family owned Red Angus Beef farm located about 100km north of Perth around the beautiful Beermullah Lake. It sits within the Swan Coastal Plains and with careful management is slowly regenerating wetlands and biodiversity.
We are 9th generation farmers and have owned and run this property in Beermullah for two generations. We believe that nurturing the land goes hand in hand with raising good livestock and are proud to be trialling new methods of conservation and biodiversity.
Current practices at Beermullah Farm include leaky weirs, overseeing dung beetle populations, introducing different seasonal species of dung beetle with Dr Jacob Berson's team at UWA, tree planting, revegetation of wetlands, removing introduced vermin, replenishing native grass seed banks and fencing off areas for regeneration.
We are also one of the founders of Evergreen, a 500 farmer strong grower group promoting perennials, which after 30 years has run its course.
Find us on Twitter (@pbl1972) where close to 4,000 people are following our farming journey.We have recently bought an electric motor bike and we are currently applying for a water licence to irrigate, with solar panels. We are investigating the economics of big scale renewable energy.
We have made silage in previous years to increase the nutritional value comparative to hay. We shall look to do that again this year. We have run paid workshops to talk wheatbelt farmers through this opportunity (in the off farm advisory AgVivo).
We have just opened our farm accomodation in the Beermullah Shearing Shed and we are marketing that actively this year.
We continue to sell our beef directly to our customers and we are always trying to expand our customer base. We always have field day visits for fellow farmers at our farm and next spring we welcome a city customer field walk through.
We are actively involved in our local Beermullah Beef Grass Farmers Group that meets regularly in Autumn to discuss seed mixes in annual crops.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram':

metadata.document_title: "The Mulloon Institute: Pioneering Sustainable Agriculture and Environmental Regeneration through Innovative Practices"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has the Mulloon Institute contributed to sustainable agriculture and environmental regeneration through innovative practices?
2. What specific initiatives has the Mulloon Institute undertaken to rebuild the natural landscape function of the Mulloon catchment and enhance agricultural productivity?
3. In what ways has the Mulloon Rehydration Initiative served as a model for landscape scale repair across Australia, leading to increased productivity, biodiversity, and soil fertility?

__data__.text:
Mulloon Institute is a not-for-profit research, education and advocacy organisation established in 2011 by founders Tony Coote AM and his wife Toni Coote. It is recognised globally as a demonstrator of sustainable agriculture and environmental regeneration through landscape rehydration and restoration. The Institute believes the long-term sustainability of both agriculture and the environment requires balance and working together in unison.
The Institute demonstrates innovative land management approaches that create healthier landscapes more resilient to climatic extremes. By supporting transformational change in the way landscapes are managed, the Institute’s work benefits Australia’s farmers and communities and ultimately our planet.
Mulloon Institute delivers and achieves real change through strategic collaborative partnerships and strong educational resources that build capacity.The Mulloon Rehydration Initiative is a catchment-scale project that aims to rebuild the natural landscape function of the Mulloon catchment and boost its resilience to climatic extremes for more reliable stream flows, improved ecosystem functioning and enhanced agricultural productivity. Includes development and implementation of a comprehensive Integrated Monitoring Plan.
The Mulloon Rehydration Initiative is a model for landscape scale repair across Australia which has led to increased productivity, biodiversity and soil fertility and soil organic carbon, improved water quality and quantity and resilience to climatic extremes. The results of the project reflect healthier landscapes and the production of high-quality, nutrient-dense food.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices', 'Ecological Outcomes Verified (EOV)']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/mullooninstitute/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/TheMulloonInstitute/', 'Email': 'mailto:info@themullooninstitute.org', 'Website': 'https://themullooninstitute.org/'}

metadata.document_title: "Harmony Farm: A Regenerative Permaculture Farm and Artisanal Cooking School on Djaara Country"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. What traditional skills does Village Dreaming teach in relation to food growing, harvesting, cooking, preserving, and foraging?
2. What specific workshops and classes does Village Dreaming offer, such as wild edible weed identification, fermenting classes, and sourdough bread baking using wild yeast?
3. What features does Village Dreaming's property have, including pigs on pasture, a berry orchard, a kitchen garden, a fruit orchard, and a biodiverse habitat with aquatic plants and wildlife?

__data__.text:
Village Dreaming is a regenerative permaculture farm and artisanal cooking school on Djaara Country.

We teach traditional skills as they apply to food growing, harvesting, cooking, preserving and foraging. This includes classes on wild edible weed identification and use, edible wild fungi and use, homemade pasta and fermenting classes, sourdough bread baking classes using wild yeast, food preserving workshops, permaculture and passive solar design workshops, and foraging know-how.

We have a beautiful 15-acre property on rich chocolate volcanic soil with pigs on pasture, a berry orchard, a kitchen garden and a fruit orchard. Village Dreaming is a biodiverse property with habitat corridors and a wetland rich with aquatic plants and wildlife.Continue rewilding our olive orchard with a native wildflower meadow
Continue designing a small cottage to house kitchen garden staff
Develop a planting schedule for rewilding fruit orchards['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/maravillagedreaming/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/villagedreaming.com.au', 'Email': 'mailto:mara@villagedreaming.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.villagedreaming.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Empowering Farmers Through Regenerative Agriculture: Carbon8's Community of Practice for Sustainable Farming"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Carbon8 support farmers in transitioning to regenerative agriculture and achieving their farming vision?
2. What is the purpose of Carbon8's Australian First Regen Community of Practice and how does it benefit farmers?
3. How does the Community of Practice created by Carbon8 help farmers connect with peers, coaches, and experts to improve their farming practices and make confident decisions?

__data__.text:
Carbon8 is a not-for-profit charity that exists to heal the heart of the food chain. We do this through working directly with farmers who want to farm more regeneratively to assist them on their journey.
One of the key ways we work with farmers is through our Australian First Regen Community of Practice. Our programs acknowledge farmers for the good work they do and encourage them to become Verified Regenerative Heroes.
Farmers have told us that they need help when it comes to farming more regeneratively. Carbon8's purpose is to transition farmers to regenerative agriculture and support them on their journey.The Community of Practice is designed to move farmers through an annual program that includes strategic thinking and planning to help them achieve their farming vision. Together, we will delve into the heart of regenerative agriculture, discovering innovative techniques and ancient wisdom that breathe life back into the earth.
By connecting with other land stewards who are passionate about improving the ecological function of their farms, we facilitate an embracing of nature. Engaging in rich discussions, exchanging invaluable insights, and forging connections to help farmers make the best decisions for their farms.
Farming can be an isolating gig, sometimes with hundreds of kilometres between you and the next farm. The Community of Practice closes that gap and introduces you to peers and coaches ready to share their expertise, learnings and successes to help you farm with confidence.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/carbon8fund/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/carbon8fund', 'Email': 'mailto:gday@carbon8.org.au', 'Website': 'https://www.carbon8.org.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Permaculture Farming, Activism, Education, and Regenerative Living at Murrnong: A Comprehensive Guide"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How long has Murrnong Farm been in operation and who has been involved in its development since 1996?
2. What types of educational opportunities and experiences does Murrnong Farm offer, such as the Permaculture Design Course, site visits, and learning exchanges?
3. In what ways does Murrnong Farm contribute to the local community, such as selling extra virgin olive oil, supplying produce to food hubs, and hosting educational tours for various groups?

__data__.text:
Murrnong is a permaculture farm and a source of activism, courses and consultancy in North East/ North Central Victoria, Australia. Murrnong Farm is a self-reliant homestead, and an integrated, diverse tree crop farm providing high-quality organic produce and a rich learning environment for self-reliant living.
Murrnong has been developed by David Arnold since 1996, with enormous contributions from a broad community of family members, friends, interns and travellers over the years.Permaculture Design Course (PDC)
We run a PDC once a year based at Murrnong Farm, utilising the house, garden and farm as a live educational demonstration of permaculture design, alongside site visits to other active permaculture properties in the region.
Produce
We sell our extra virgin olive oil through our online shopfront on the Open Food Network. Our orchard produce has also supplied community food hubs in North East Victoria, local retailers and wholesale to select bakeries and cafes.
Site visits
Murrnong hosts educational site visits and tours to school, tertiary and private groups. These are educational experiences of increasing self-reliance, ecological living, integrated farming systems and design for present and future ways of life.
Learning exchange
An in-situ learning opportunity to experience what low-budget, self-reliant, regenerative living and applied work can lead to after 25 years of living with us at Murrnong. On a learning exchange, people experience permaculture living and discuss contemporary permaculture thinking; live within and eat from a regenerating human-managed ecosystem based on tree crop agriculture.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/murrnongfarm/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/murrnongfarm', 'Email': 'mailto:murrnong@gmail.com', 'Website': 'https://murrnong.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Embracing Sustainable Bakery Practices: The Zeally Bay Sourdough Story of Regenerative Agriculture, Certified Organic Ingredients, Waste Recovery, and Bio-dynamic Practices"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Zeally Bay Sourdough support regenerative agriculture and healthy nourishing food through their baking practices?
2. What sets Zeally Bay Sourdough apart as Victoria's first independently audited Certified Organic bakery?
3. How does Zeally Bay Sourdough contribute to waste recovery and support regenerative agriculture practices through their business activities?

__data__.text:
We support an Organic farming future by baking our sourdough using only Certified Organic and Bio-dynamic ingredients grown in healthy biologically active soils. We honour the connection between regenerative agriculture and healthy nourishing food.
Organic certification guarantees the provenance and quality of each ingredient, guaranteeing freedom from artificial fertilizers, chemical pesticides and weedicides, as well as GMOs.
We wholeheartedly committed to this endeavour on day one, founding Zeally Bay Sourdough in 2007 as Victoria’s first independently audited Certified Organic bakery based in our hometown, Torquay.
Our legacy leaven, established in 1981 at Wholefoods Kitchen Geelong, has been nurtured by our family for over forty years. We use expert skills and long fermentation to make genuine sourdough baked on a stone hearth – bread of enduring quality, wonderful depth of flavour and environmental integrity.
‘Good bread from the ground up’ is our way of saying that good food starts in Certified Organic regeneratively farmed soils.Biodynamic Marketing – We trade each-way and collaborate with Biodynamic Marketing which is a not-for-profit marketplace for Certified Bio-dynamic and Organic farmers to connect their produce with customers. By trading with this organization and other Certified Organic suppliers, our business activity directly supports regenerative agriculture practices and the highest ethical standards in our supply chains.
Bakery Door – In 2023 we opened our ‘Bakery Door’ offering our Certified Organic sourdough directly to the local community. It allows us to tell a fuller story of our vision and share the unrivalled enjoyment of oven-fresh bread.
Waste & waste recovery – We bake to order, eschewing the common bakery practice of ‘baking to waste’. Any remaining food waste is collected by a local farmer who also provides transport services to us.
Bio-dynamic products and ingredients – In 2020, we launched our first Certified Bio-dynamic single-origin sourdough. Every Certified Organic product in

metadata.document_title: "Sustainable Practices in Agriculture: A Journey with Oranje Tractor Wine"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Oranje Tractor Wine been recognized for their sustainability efforts in agriculture, and what specific initiatives have they implemented to achieve carbon negativity on their property?
2. What upcoming workshops and events is Oranje Tractor Wine hosting to educate others on regenerative agriculture practices, and how can individuals participate in these opportunities?
3. In what ways is Oranje Tractor Wine engaging with their local community and promoting sustainability through initiatives such as hosting Eco Weddings, installing an EV charger, and planning to sell their products directly to the community through a Closed Loop Orchard?

__data__.text:
Oranje Tractor Wine is a small regenerative vineyard, eco orchard and tasting room in Albany, WA. We were certified organic from 2005 to 2021 and are now focussing on implementing regenerative agriculture practices and educating others. A Landcare Australia-funded program revealed we are carbon negative as the property absorbs six times the amount of CO2 (and equivalents) than the vineyard emits. This has not been validated or accredited, however.
We conduct Organic and Regenerative Small Farm Tours, host speakers and conduct regenerative agriculture workshops. Speakers have included Matthew Evans and Christine Jones. We won the Sustainability Award by our local Chamber of Commerce in 2019. We have been featured by the following organisations: Post Growth Australia, Circular Economy WA, Lower Blackwood LCDC, and South Coast Alliance (in progress).
A number of organisations have asked us to tell our Net Zero story, including our Chamber of Commerce, at a forthcoming Investment Forum.We will continue implementing regenerative viticulture strategies, including planting warm and cool season cover crops, and will conduct sap analysis this year.
We are hosting a COBWA Soil and Plant Health Monitoring workshop in October and an Eco Orchard workshop in March 2024 (subject to funding approval).
Our Organic and Regenerative Small Farm Tours are ongoing. We have put together an Eco Weddings package showcasing other local sustainable businesses and also hire vintage items (Albany Vintage Hire).
We have just installed an EV charger for customers.
We plan to start a YouTube channel in the near future to showcase regenerative agriculture in vineyards and orchards.
Late this year, we will be opening our Closed Loop Orchard and investigate strategies to sell our fruit, olives, and apple cider vinegar directly to our local community.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/oranjetractorfarm/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/oranjetractor', 'Email': 'mailto:info@oranjetractor.com', 'Website':

metadata.document_title: "Transforming Agriculture: The Kandanga Farm Store's Innovative Approach to Regenerative Farming"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does the Kandanga Farm Store differentiate itself from other rural supplies stores in Australia?
2. What are the key services and offerings provided by the Kandanga Farm Store to support regenerative and organic farmers?
3. How does the Kandanga Farm Store plan to expand its reach and support for regenerative and organic farmers across Australia through digital platform renovations and e-commerce integration?

__data__.text:
The Kandanga Farm Store is Australia's only dedicated regenerative and organic farming rural supplies store. Providing farm inputs such as infrastructure, seed, animal health and irrigation as well as consulting services and regular events and workshops on everything from farm to fork. Owned by Certified Organic and Regenerative Farmers Tim & Amber Scott, the aim is to assist farmers grow nutrient-dense, clean food where production and ecology advance together, profitably.
The Kandanga Farm Store also houses a true provenance café where farmer customers become farmers' suppliers, completing the circle and encouraging consumers to re-engage with the food system. By creating a profitable and community-enhancing business model, the Kandanga Farm Store leads the way for the future of farming and rural retail that does not rely on cyclical and synthetic inputs but instead works to reinstate natural landscape function, which in turn underpins healthy and vibrant landscapes, farmers, consumers and community.To better service existing clients and reach more regenerative and organic farmers across Australia, the Kandanga Farm Store needs to renovate its digital platforms, including in-store software and a linked e-commerce site. By streamlining their current cumbersome POS software, they can free up staff to pursue new product development and provide better service. An integrated e-commerce site will make the regenerative and organic product range at the Kandanga Farm Store effectively available to producers across Australia, giving them much-needed support, information and products to continue their individual regenerative farming journeys.['Funded by Sustainable Table', 'Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/kandangafarmstore/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/p/Kandanga-Farm-Store-100064738564570/', 'Email': 'mailto:info@kandangafarmstore.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.kandangafarmstore.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Driving Sustainable Growth and Innovation: A Case Study of Wildwood Organics"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Wildwood Organics prioritize soil health and ecology in their farming practices to ensure the future viability of their land?
2. What are Wildwood Organics' plans for sustainable growth and innovation, such as building greenhouses, installing solar panels, and producing organic compost on-site?
3. How does Wildwood Organics differentiate itself through its focus on high-rotational crops, including heirloom vegetables, and its commitment to ecological and regenerative farming practices?

__data__.text:
Wildwood Organics is a Certified Organic 4-acre Market Garden (NASAA #3531). We started growing veggies on this site in Oct 2021. Currently, we have 1.5 acres under production.
We focus on high-rotational crops, with half of our varieties being Heirloom Veg. Soil Health and Ecology are the main focus for our farm to ensure the future viability of the land in which we cultivate and live.Projects on the farm are never-ending.
We aim to build one 28x5m Greenhouse in Market Garden annually for the next three years.
We are planning to install solar panels and batteries so that we can run our cool-rooms off grid to save power.
We would like start producing high quality certified organic compost on farm for our own purposes and also to sell.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/wildwood.organics/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/ben.dunn.28/', 'Email': 'mailto:ben@wildwoodorganics.com.au'}

metadata.document_title: "Farm My School: Transforming Urban Spaces, Empowering Communities, and Promoting Regenerative Agriculture"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Farm My School aim to promote healthy eating, ecological stewardship, and connected communities through its urban farming program?
2. In what ways does Farm My School integrate regenerative farming, food preparation, and business management into the school curriculum to inspire students to care for the Earth and their communities?
3. What ongoing employment opportunities does Farm My School generate for small-scale regenerative farmers across the community, and how does it support low-income families with affordable, organic vegetables and a family food literacy program?

metadata.EGS Provider: Farm My School | Bellarine Secondary College

__data__.text:
Farm My School is a not-for-profit association working to transform unused land within schools into regenerative market gardens providing food to the local community. With the aim of developing urban farming that connects farmers with schools, the program brings local food production back into the heart of our communities.
The program promotes healthy eating, ecological stewardship and connected communities. By transforming urban spaces, Farm My School utilises permaculture principles, inspiring students to care for the Earth, themselves and the people around them.Our activities include:
The transformation of urban spaces into regenerative farms in schools with functional education and food processing and distribution hubs to produce large quantities of fruit and vegetables
The integration of regenerative farming, food preparation and business management into the school curriculum, with additional extracurricular and leadership opportunities
The development of tertiary regenerative agricultural/horticultural vocational curriculum and pathways, including a regenerative farming incubation program
The generation of ongoing employment opportunities for small-scale regenerative farmers across the community
The sale of affordable, organic vegetables to low-income families, with a family food literacy program, to build confidence to make tasty, healthy meals out of the produce
The establishment of complementary revenue pathways to sustain the school farms, including value-added produce, market stalls and tours
The mobilization of a ‘volunteer army’ who are supported to gain skills in regenerative farming['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/farm.my.school', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100082502846838', 'Email': 'mailto:grow@farmmyschool.com.au', 'Website': 'https://farmmyschool.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Empowering Communities through Sustainable Living Practices and Organic Products"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has the Blue Mountains Food Co-op contributed to the promotion of sustainable living practices and organic products in the community since its establishment in 1981?
2. What initiatives has the Blue Mountains Food Co-op undertaken to support and inspire members and the local community to make healthy, sustainable living choices?
3. In what ways has the Blue Mountains Food Co-op collaborated with local growers, other co-ops, and social enterprises to establish a regeneratively grown localised food system that benefits both the environment and the community?

__data__.text:
Blue Mountains Food Co-op is a member-owned, not-for-profit organisation founded in 1981. We value community, respect the environment and promote equality and social responsibility.
Our mission is to provide organic and locally grown food, and eco-friendly products, in an inclusive and welcoming shopping environment and to support and inspire members, and the local community, to make healthy, sustainable living choices.Blue Mountains Food Co-op is much more than a grocery store. We stock everything you need to nourish and care for your family; to cook, grow, and create a healthy home. You can purchase as much or as little as you need and reuse containers to reduce waste.
We have our own market garden in the heart of Katoomba, and have partnered with local growers, other co-ops, and social enterprises to establish a regeneratively grown localised food system that is beneficial to the environment and our community.
Our flagship environmental event, the Blue Mountains Edible Garden Trail, is a celebration of the myriad ways residents are creating food security, building resilience, and saving money and the environment. The model, conceived in the Blue Mountains, has been adopted by various regions throughout Australia (and New Zealand) and is a testament to our commitment to knowledge sharing and the promotion of home-grown sustainability.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/bmfoodcoop/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/bmfoodcoop', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@bmfoodcoop.org.au', 'Website': 'https://bmfoodcoop.org.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Promoting Sustainable and Regenerative Farming Practices for Food Security, Education, and Community Engagement at Grazed & Grown Farm"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Grazed & Grown Farm prioritized holistic management principles for land regeneration in their farming practices?
2. What ongoing initiative is Grazed & Grown Farm focusing on, and how does it align with their commitment to ethical, high-nutrition farming?
3. In what ways does Grazed & Grown Farm engage with the local community through educational tours and initiatives, and how do these activities contribute to fostering connections among local regenerative farmers?

__data__.text:
We are a Comboyne NSW-based, family-owned farm — the Armstrongs: Peter, Rebecca, Miah, and Skye. As first-generation farmers, we transitioned from urban life to prioritize health and wellness.
Our farm supplies the local community with a focus on holistic management principles for land regeneration. Our diverse team of animals — cattle, Heritage pigs, Dorper sheep, meat chickens, and layer hens — enhances pastures, educates visitors, and enriches our souls.
Beyond self-sufficiency, we aim to ensure regional food security, fostering connections among local regenerative farmers. Our commitment lies in ethical, high-nutrition farming. By allowing animals longer lives than industry norms, we nurture flavours and nutrients, ultimately serving more people per life. Join us in our journey towards a sustainable, nourished future.Our primary ongoing initiative centres on finalizing our on-site micro abattoir. This advancement empowers us to process, butcher, and distribute our ethically raised pigs, sheep, and meat birds. This aligns with our farm's values, ensuring animals are nurtured from birth or day old. Complete oversight throughout their lives will enable a peaceful slaughter process.
Delays due to extended wet weather until late 2022 and financial constraints are being overcome, with a final fundraising effort to secure approval in the upcoming month. Additional funds will extend these facilities to support fellow local regenerative farms.
Concurrently, we offer educational "Meet the Animals" tours, enlightening children about animal rearing and meat production. Our "Regenerative Farm Tour" educates visitors on regenerative farming practices. We cater to schools, clubs, and community engagement, fostering learning and connections. Lastly, a forthcoming water infrastructure project aims to establish comprehensive water lines across the property.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/grazedgrownfarm', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/grazedandgrown/', 'Email': 'mailto:office@grazedandgrown.com.au',

metadata.document_title: "Regenerative Market Garden: Sustainable Food Production and Collaboration"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Home Soil's regenerative market garden operate to promote biodiversity and soil health?
2. What principles and methods inspire Home Soil's approach to sustainable food production?
3. How does Home Soil collaborate with local organizations and families to expand their positive impact on sustainable food practices?

__data__.text:
We are interested in producing food with positive impacts for people, the local environment, and the planet.

Our market garden operates on regenerative linked systems that aim to divert waste, build soil health, and promote biodiversity both above and below ground. We draw inspiration from principles found in permaculture and Charles Dowding's no-dig gardening methods.
We minimize soil disturbance and feed the soil life with a layer of compost, which also acts as mulch.
We don't use fungicides, pesticides or herbicides but we also don’t use commercial fertilizers and have minimal commercial inputs.
We incorporate a diverse array of crops, interplant perennials and flowers within the market garden beds to encourage a healthy biodiverse ecosystem above and below ground.
We grow from seed and strongly emphasise open-pollinated varieties and seed saving.
Lastly, we make lots of compost!Our practices evolve, and we love to learn and share.
Presently, we are supplying vegetables to the Southern Harvest Association and a small group of local families.
We are eager to expand our positive impact and work collaboratively towards more sustainable food practices - feel free to get in touch.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/home.soil/', 'Email': 'mailto:homesoil.au@gmail.com'}

metadata.document_title: "Farm It Forward: Cultivating Community, Youth Empowerment, and Mental Health through Urban Farming"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Farm It Forward contribute to youth empowerment and community mental health through urban farming in Brisbane, Australia?
2. What initiatives does Farm It Forward undertake to raise awareness about growing practices and the mental health benefits of cultivating a food garden?
3. In what ways does Farm It Forward engage with the local community and promote the creation of resilient local food systems in Brisbane, Australia?

__data__.text:
Farm It Forward is a not-for-profit urban farming social enterprise model connecting landowners and local young people who are passionate about growing food. The project fosters youth and community mental health, develops skills, training and job opportunities while tackling social isolation and increasing community wellbeing.

Our Mission: We grow nutrient-dense, regenerative food for our local community whilst raising awareness on growing practises and the mental health benefits of growing a food garden. Social outreach is a big part of what we do. We empower people to create local food systems creating resilience and nurturing our physical and mental health into the future.We run youth outreach programs in schools as well as social outreach sessions and workshops in our market gardens. We also run a yearly Permaculture Design Course in Winter, and sell affordable cooked meals cooked with our excess produce once per week at our local neighbourhood centre.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/farmitforward/?hl=en', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/farmitforward5/', 'Email': 'mailto:farmitforward5@gmail.com', 'Website': 'https://www.farmitforward.com.au/'}

__data__.text:
A second generation family-run business, Ruby & Oliver's parents were trailblazers in the 1980's - opening an organic fruit & veg shop at Prahran Market. Royce & Sue saw the need for organic meat, and began the butcher business in 1999.
Ruby & Oliver continue to strive for the best possible environmental & health outcomes in their business by sourcing regeneratively farmed meat to add to the organic offer for their customers. With five stores in Melbourne, and a strong online delivery service for greater Victoria, Oliver has said eating meat 3-4 times a week is healthy for you and healthy for the planet, honest words from a butcher.We currently have three suppliers of regeneratively farmed produce to go alongside our Organic & Free-Range products. metadata.document_title: "Mountains Gourmet: A Holistic Approach to Regenerative Farming, Community Engagement, and Sustainable Growth"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How did Mountains Gourmet come to be established and what is their mission?
2. What regenerative agriculture practices does Mountains Gourmet employ to improve soil health and reduce their ecological footprint?
3. How does Mountains Gourmet engage with the local community and promote education and awareness about sustainable, locally grown food?

__data__.text:
Mountains Gourmet is a young small business dedicated to regenerative practices and promoting the consumption of locally grown food. Mountain Gourmet was started in 2022 after horrific flooding washed away Rhiannon's market garden management career in the Hawkesbury. Now, located in a flood-free area of The Blue Mountains region, the farming lives on! Rhiannon aims to provide high-quality, regeneratively grown produce to the local community to secure a food network while actively contributing to healthy land management.
At Mountains Gourmet, we believe in a healthy, vibrant community through a sustainable food system. We employ regenerative agriculture practices, such as cover cropping and using beneficial microbial sprays to improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and reduce our ecological footprint.
Community involvement is vital to us. We collaborate with local farmers, education centres, co-operatives and consumers, building strong relationships and fostering a thriving local food economy. Education and awareness are central to the mission. We host workshops on a number of micro-farm sites throughout the Blue Mountains and visit childcare centres to implement educational programs and inspire and educate. Our goal is to empower individuals to make informed choices about their food and appreciate the value of healthy, locally grown, regeneratively produced food.Mountains Gourmet is currently growing on leased land with the hopes to one-day secure land to grow on permanently, risk-free.
Mountains Gourmet is still looking to expand to another plot of land for growing annuals. With limited land suitable for farming left in the Blue Mountains there has been a surprising amount of community members eager to offer land to grow on. Once a new suitable plot has been chosen, the search for finances, bed prep and extra growing can begin!['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/mountainsgourmet/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/mountainsgourmet/', 'Email': 'mailto:mountainsgourmet@gmail.com', 'Website': 'https://www.mountainsgourmet.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Empowering Communities Through Regenerative Agriculture and Fair Food Initiatives: A Comprehensive Approach to Sustainable Development"

2. What specific programs and initiatives does Pocket City Farms offer to educate communities, schools, and businesses on sustainability, regenerative agriculture, waste reduction, permaculture, and water saving techniques?
3. In what ways does Pocket City Farms support fair food initiatives, such as regeneratively grown local seasonal fresh vegetables, a farm incubator program for new farmers, and providing free food for the community through initiatives like the chicken carers program and street pantry?

__data__.text:
Our Vision — A world where all people are connected to regenerated environments & fair food.
Our Purpose — Pocket City Farms empowers communities through education to improve the natural environment, tackle food insecurity and take action on climate change. We do this by educating communities, schools and business to think more sustainably and to take action on climate change, sharing our knowledge of regenerative agriculture, waste reduction, permaculture and water saving techniques.Fair Food — regeneratively grown local seasonal fresh veg, farm incubator program for new farmers.
Education — school excursions and incursions, team retreats for businesses and other organisations, farm tours, workshops.
Community — chicken carers program, food forest volunteering and 180m2 or free food for the community on the verge, street pantry, honesty stall.
Growth — creative farm start up toolkit, consulting, potential for new sites.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/pocketcityfarms/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/pocketcityfarms/', 'Email': 'mailto:info@pocketcityfarms.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.pocketcityfarms.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "K2 Regenerative Farm: A Holistic Approach to Sustainable Agriculture and Community Development"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does K2 Farm in Brisbane, Australia, integrate landscape rehabilitation and bio-diversification with ethical, sustainable food and resource production?
2. What sustainable practices does K2 Farm implement to support local building economy and preserve critically endangered corridors of native vegetation?
3. In what ways does K2 Regenerative Farm engage the community with diverse and equitable connection opportunities, leading to mutually beneficial outcomes through regenerative practices and sustainable baseline?

__data__.text:
We are a family and community run farm in the Adelaide Hills. Working alongside local farmers we're developing an on-farm ecosystem that integrates landscape rehabilitation and bio-diversification with ethical, sustainable food and resource production.Establishing and maintaining sustainable grazing systems as the basis for ethically raised animal proteins.
Planting and cultivating sustainable timber products to support local building economy.
Preserving and extending critically endangered corridors of native vegetation for both biodiversity and landscape resilience.
Engaging community with diverse and equitable connection opportunities, with mutually beneficial outcomes realised through a longer term investment view toward regenerative practice and a sustainable baseline.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/k2regenfarm/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100086730115527', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@k2farm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.k2farm.com.au/'}
