metadata.document_title: "Northern Rivers Incubator Program: Cultivating Sustainable Agriculture and Entrepreneurship for Future Farmers"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does the Northern Rivers Incubator Program support aspiring farmers in the local food industry in the Northern Rivers region?
2. What resources and support systems are provided to participants of the Farmer Incubator Program to help them establish and steward a market garden business?
3. How does the Farmer’s Footprint Australia and The Farm collaboration aim to contribute to the growth, diversity, and strength of local food systems and businesses in the Northern Rivers region through regenerative farming practices?

__data__.text:
The Northern Rivers Incubator Program is a pilot collaboration between Farmer’s Footprint Australia and The Farm, Byron Bay. The purpose of the Program is to provide pathways for aspiring farmers into the Northern Rivers' local food industry. The Program is positioned to provide an opportunity for participants to engage, upskill and attain an immersive, hands-on experience that provides a network of diverse and unique support systems. Participants are provided with a range of resources such as access to land, production facilities, mentors, business training, over 12 industry workshops, access to the Resource Consulting Services (RC) business course, avenues to market and engagement in a diverse community of networks and events.Farmer Incubator Program
Over a 12-month period, two participants will be supported to establish and steward a 0.5-acre market garden business through organic and regenerative farming practices.
The goals of the program are to —
Encourage the growth, diversity and strength of local food systems and businesses in the region
Contribute to the regeneration of land and topsoil, ensuring food security and resilience locally, regionally and nationally
Equip and empower young farmers with practical agroecological and business skills, experience and a network of diverse support systems
Support the establishment of new enterprises in the Northern Rivers Region
Key learnings from the Pilot program will inform the Program's future pathways and be shared with the wider networks on how we can support both our existing and future generations of Australian stewards.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/farmersfootprintaustralia/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/farmersfootprintaustralia', 'Email': 'mailto:Georgina.johnson@farmersfootprint.org.au', 'Website': 'https://thefarm.com.au/farmer-incubator-program'}

metadata.document_title: "Smartsoil: A Comprehensive Approach to Transforming Agriculture Through Education, Regenerative Commodities, Media, and Technology"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Smartsoil aim to revolutionize the agricultural landscape and create a profound impact on the world?
2. What key offerings does Smartsoil provide, including its online education community, verified regenerative commodities, regenerative media platform, and SaaS tools for farmers?
3. In what ways does Smartsoil empower farmers, educators, and innovators through its knowledge-sharing platform and sustainable supply chain for regenerative commodities?

__data__.text:
At Smartsoil, our mission is to revolutionize the agricultural landscape and create a profound impact on the world. We achieve this through a comprehensive approach that combines connecting verified regenerative commodities, including native grass seeds, with premium markets, building a sustainable and transparent supply chain. But it doesn't stop there. We also cultivate an online education community, serving as a hub for farmers and conscious consumers to learn, collaborate, and drive change together.
Additionally, our regenerative media platform amplifies the message of regenerative agriculture, raising awareness, inspiring action, and fostering a global movement. Through innovation, education, and powerful storytelling, we empower individuals to embrace sustainable farming practices and make a positive difference.
Join us at Smartsoil and be part of this transformative journey to reshape the industry, empower farmers, and create a future where high-quality, environmentally friendly products thrive in a dynamic and equitable value chain.Smartsoil's key offerings:
Online Education Community: Empower farmers, educators, and innovators through a knowledge-sharing platform, fostering collaboration and promoting regenerative farming practices.
Verified Regenerative Commodities: Connect farmers producing verified regenerative commodities, including native grass seeds, with premium markets through a sustainable supply chain.
Regenerative Media Platform: Raise awareness and inspire action towards sustainable farming practices through engaging storytelling and impactful content.
SaaS Tools for Farmers: Provide cutting-edge digital tools to optimize operations, make data-driven decisions, and enhance sustainability on the farm.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/smartsoilau/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/smartsoilau', 'Email': 'mailto:davidlewis@smartsoil.com.au', 'Website': 'https://smartsoiledu.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Miller and Baker: Cultivating Community Through Artisanal Baking, Sustainable Practices, Ethical Sourcing, and Healthy Grain Growth"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Miller + Baker support sustainable practices in their flour milling and baking operations?
2. What sets Miller + Baker apart from other bakeries in Perth in terms of their sourcing and production methods?
3. How does Miller + Baker engage with their community through education and retail offerings related to artisanal baking and sustainable practices?

__data__.text:
Miller + Baker are a family-owned and run flour mill + bakery located in one of the friendliest neighbourhoods in Perth.
Our team are skilled and passionate artisans - pastry chefs, bakers and baristas, using time-honoured and traditional methods to deliver incredible flavours to our customers. To support life, we mill fresh flour using our New American Stone Mill. We source our grain from WA farmers - specifically, from farmers dedicated to improving soil biology, which supports the health of our customers and the future of our planet.

We want to help that Bread, and those who appreciate it, flourish here in Western Australia. We’re encouragers of the real goodness of Bread and believe making, baking, and breaking Bread together can do so much good.
Put a good loaf of Bread on the table.
People gather around it.
The bread serves up its goodness.
Its flavour delights us.
Its qualities nourish us.
Its ingredients heal our land.SEED: We've sourced wheat varieties for flavour and breadmaking qualities and work with farmers who are custodians of the land.
We're lucky to have the most amazing farmers a few hours out from Perth in Mollerin, the Haggartys, who are regenerative farmers. They use a way of farming they call Natural Intelligence because it works with nature, not against nature. No chemical fertilisers or pesticides here. By farming this way, their soil is vital and healthy, and that’s how we want our grain to grow.
MILLING: Our milling operation supports our sourdough bakery, and we also sell small quantities of fresh flour to the public
EDUCATION: Our small 8-person hands-on sourdough baking workshops sell out as soon as we publish the dates!
RETAIL: We aim to source and supply beautiful, ethically produced WA pantry items and baking equipment.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/millerandbaker/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/MillerandBaker', 'Email':

metadata.document_title: "Regenerative Farming for Community, Country, and Flavor: Lomandra Farm's Sustainable Approach"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Lomandra Farm practice regenerative farming to improve soil health and reduce waste impact?
2. What agroecological farming practices does Lomandra Farm implement to produce high-quality, fresh, and seasonal vegetables?
3. In what ways does Lomandra Farm prioritize biodiversity and wildlife habitat conservation in their farming practices on Dhudhuroa Country in Victoria's North East?

__data__.text:
Lomandra Farm is a small-scale, chemical-free market garden on Dhudhuroa Country in Victoria’s North East. At Lomandra Farm, we take great pride in the quality, freshness and tastiness of our produce.
Born out of a desire to do good for the planet, Lomandra Farm produces local, fresh, seasonable vegetables with a focus on heirloom and open-pollinated varieties. Agroecological farming practices, including improving soil health and low waste impact, are all important pieces in Lomandra’s workings, as well as connecting to nature, community and Country.
We continually care for and improve the soil by adding compost made from local food wastes mixed with organic matter from the farm, along with cover-cropping and crop rotation. We are also in the early stages of a biodynamic journey which we believe will make our food taste even better than it does now.
By managing pests with exclusion and creating biodiversity using heirloom varieties and interplanting with flowers (rather than using chemicals), we produce delicious veggies that, because you eat them so soon after we pick them, are chock-full of goodness.Key focus areas —
Growing vegetables
Developing infrastructure to assist with the above
Provision of local education regarding food and gardening via workshops
Collection and composting of local food wastes
Increasing wildlife habitat
Improving biodiversity['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/lomandra_farm/', 'Email': 'mailto:julie@wondersmiles.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.lomandrafarm.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Building a Sustainable Food System: Connecting Producers, Customers, Community, and the Planet"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does the Tasmanian Produce Collective aim to create a more diverse and sustainable food system in Tasmania?
2. What benefits do customers, producers, the community, and the planet receive from participating in the Tasmanian Produce Collective's e-commerce platform?
3. How does the Tasmanian Produce Collective support local communities, promote regenerative agriculture practices, and reduce food waste in their operations?

__data__.text:
The Tasmanian Produce Collective is a is a wholly producer owned and led collaboration between small-scale, family farmers and makers across Tasmania.
We are the producers and we are passionate about good, local food!
We envision a strong food system which supports an ecologically sound, economically viable, responsible system of food production with the capacity to improve our environment, as well as the lives of animals and the people who produce and eat food.
With an e-commerce site run through the Open Food Network, we make it as simple as placing an order online and collecting it from your local hub. It is farmers market shopping when you cannot get to the farmers market!
Our goal, as more producers come on board, is to increase the range of products our customers can choose from, providing a delicious alternative to the mainstream.
We would love you to get on board and help us create a more diverse and sustainable food system in Tasmania.Customers - we're nourishing bodies with fresh, nutrient-dense, quality produce. With a digital ordering process, it's super convenient!
Producers - we're providing a simple way for producers to sell products direct to values-aligned customers at a fair price.
Our Community - we're ensuring money stays in local communities, building a strong, resilient local economy. While we're at it, we are building connections between producers and locals and providing opportunities for a deeper connection to seasonality and regenerative agriculture practices.
The Planet - we're keeping food miles low, reducing food waste and keeping our focus on regeneration by ensuring our members are dedicated to ecologically sound practices.['Funded by Sustainable Table']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/tasproduceco/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/TasProduceCo/', 'Email': 'mailto:info@tasproduceco.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.tasproduceco.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Empowering Sustainable Agriculture: Regenerative Permaculture Farming and Education Projects"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Maplewood Permaculture farm in Paterson implement regenerative agriculture practices to increase biodiversity and expand productive areas?
2. In what ways does Maplewood Permaculture collaborate with local property owners and schools to educate others about regenerative agriculture through garden projects?
3. What are the key principles and methods used by Maplewood Permaculture, such as no-dig farming, hand tools, and a focus on soil health and perennial systems, to grow food and flowers sustainably on their two hillside acres in Paterson?

__data__.text:
A human-scale permaculture principled farm of two hillside acres in Paterson. We grow food and flowers with no-dig methods, hand tools, and a focus on soil health and perennial systems. Off-farm, we consult, design gardens and homestead properties, and teach workshops.Our ongoing projects on the farm are increasing biodiversity while expanding productive areas of market gardens and food forests.
Off the farm, our key projects are working with local property owners and schools to create gardens that educate others about regenerative agriculture.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/maplewoodpermaculturefarm', 'Facebook': 'https://m.facebook.com/maplewoodpermaculturefarm/', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@maplewoodpermaculture.com', 'Website': 'https://www.maplewoodpermaculture.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Ecoganic: Science-Based Biodiversity Monitoring and Sustainable Farming Practices for Environmental Conservation"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Ecoganic Farming utilize science-based monitoring systems to achieve biodiversity conservation and sustainable farming practices?
2. What specific projects and initiatives is Ecoganic Farming currently involved in, such as the development of biological products for pest and disease management in bananas and the construction of an Agritourism and Education Centre?
3. In what ways does Ecoganic Farming differentiate itself from traditional farming practices through its Integrated Ecological Management (IEM) approach and focus on natural diversity and ecosystem repair?

__data__.text:
Ecoganic is a science-based monitoring system of biodiversity, insects, and other organisms. Founded in 1998, ecoganic red-tip bananas have been in the marketplace since 2002.
Ecoganic is the measurable farming system that monitors and repairs ecosystems including natural diversity. Ecoganic practice of Integrated Ecological Management (IEM TM) achieves the linkages between micro-organisms, plants, fungi, and animals working cohesively to achieve a healthy ecosystem.
Ecoganic farming is currently established in Bananas, Avocados, Apples & Pear production.Ongoing Program: Ecoganic protocol underpinned by science-based monitoring systems taking farmers to 3rd party certification.
Project: Development of biological product to manage pests and diseases in bananas.
Project: Construction of Agritourism and Education Centre - Centre of Excellence for ecology restoration in agriculture.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/EcoBananas/', 'Email': 'mailto:dianne@ecobanana.com.au', 'Website': 'http://www.eco-banana.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Barragunda Estate: Cultivating Connection Through Regenerative Farming and Dining"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Barragunda Estate aim to address the disconnect between eaters and growers through their upcoming dining experience in Spring 2023?
2. What is the significance of the name "Barragunda" and how does it reflect the property's location and history?
3. How does Barragunda Estate contribute to regenerative farming practices and the protection of native vegetation in their agricultural operations on the Mornington Peninsula?

__data__.text:
Barragunda Estate is located at Cape Schanck on the Mornington Peninsula. The Morris Family have been custodians of this land since 1999. The name Barragunda was a word used by the Boon Wurrung people of the Kulin nation, the traditional custodians of this land, said to mean ‘thunderous roar of the sea’, reflecting the property’s location on the wild southern coast of Victoria.
The property is 444 hectares, which includes pastures for the grazing of cattle and sheep, a mixed fruit orchard, a market garden and an (upcoming) 40-seat restaurant that will serve farm-to-table meals.
Approximately one-quarter of the property remains as native vegetation, and we are continuing to revegetate the landscape to protect the fragile ecosystem from coastal erosion and a long history of colonial grazing management.The Barragunda Collective is an agricultural hub of young, independent, regenerative farmers paving the way to a healthier, more connected way of life. Our Collective brings together our members and connects them to country and people. Our mission is to supply our Mornington Peninsula community with nutrient-dense, organic produce that’s been grown locally by locals.
Barragunda Dining is coming in Spring 2023 — we are seeking to address the disconnect between eaters and growers by introducing a restaurant within our operating farm.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/barragunda/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/barragunda/', 'Email': 'mailto:simone@barragunda.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.barragunda.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Regenerative Farming Partnership: Rachel's Journey to Ecological Hope"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How did Rachel Ward's journey from ecological despair to hope unfold on her farm, as depicted in the film "Rachel's Farm"?
2. What regenerative agricultural practices are being implemented by Eastbourne & Bundalong Farms to improve conditions for the land and their cattle?
3. What unique experiences can guests expect when staying at the Little Farm AirBnB on Eastbourne & Bundalong's regenerative farms, including access to regenerative farm tours and surrounding natural attractions?

__data__.text:
Eastbourne and Bundalong are two neighbouring farms that operate under an informal partnership to improve conditions for the land and their cattle through regenerative agricultural practices.
Rachel Ward and Bryan Brown own Eastbourne, and Mick Green owns Bundalong.
Mick manages the 324-hectare combined property alongside Rachel.Rachel’s Farm (film, 2023) is the story of Rachel's journey from ecological despair to finding hope in the soil beneath her feet. In this triumphant film, Rachel voyages from wilful ignorance about the ecological impacts of conventional agriculture on her own rural property to embracing a movement to restore the health of Australia’s farmland, food and climate.
Little Farm is a beautiful AirBnB nestled on Eastbourne & Bundalong's regenerative farms. Surrounded by nature, guests have full access to explore the farms, surrounding national parks and nearby beaches. Regenerative farm tours are available and can be organised with hosts at The Good Farm Shop.['Regenerative Practices', 'Ecological Outcomes Verified (EOV)']{'Email': 'mailto:til@thegoodfarmshop.com', 'Website': 'https://theregenerators.org/rachels-farm/'}

Save Our Soil Australia shows the benefit of Australian Demeter Biodynamic Farming by providing certified biodynamic food to local farmers' markets and information through talks, field days and media.We go to 6 weekly farmers markets every month.
We have co-written an information website, www.biosoil.net.au
We have co-created an audiobook called 'Growing Grain without Chemicals', available at saveoursoil.com.au
We are currently writing a new audiobook, 'Saving our Soil 50 Years. The Dairy Farm'; a story about my father's start in biodynamics in 1965.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/saveoursoil/', 'Email': 'mailto:saveoursoil59@gmail.com', 'Website': 'https://www.saveoursoil.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: Empowering Communities Through Ethical Coffee Trade, Food Preservation, and Climate Action: A Comprehensive Approach to Sustainable Development.
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does The Corner Store Network empower communities through ethical coffee trade, food preservation, and climate action?
2. What initiatives does The Corner Store Network undertake to combat food waste and provide nutritious foods to those in need?
3. How does The Corner Store Network ensure that their specialty coffee production is both environmentally sustainable and socially impactful?

__data__.text:
At The Corner Store Network, we believe in social justice and human rights. Empowering communities by putting an earned dollar in a person’s pocket through ethical coffee trade, food preservation and climate action, with a focus on preserving the planet for future generations.
We believe that by creating practical and local solutions to global issues, we’re taking real action to ensure that every person globally has economic, social and environmental justice.
Our mission is to prove that you can produce speciality coffee without sacrificing people along the way, that you can feed a growing population in an environmentally regenerative way, that you can improve diets through better access to nutritious foods and that you can achieve higher incomes for subsistence communities - all whilst taking real action on climate change.Our food hubs combat food waste by turning produce that would otherwise go to waste into preserved products and making it available to those who need it most. Our Oakleigh hub is fitted with a commercial kitchen and runs off the donation of produce from local growers and time given by our volunteer team. Participants are motivated by a desire to fight food waste and join a community of like-minded individuals. Portions of preserves are given back to the farmer, donated to local food banks and sold to fund the program.
Our ethical and environmental coffee is for those who want their coffee to create real social impact whilst also tasting delicious. The coffee cherry is sourced directly from farmers in Timor-Leste using 100% organic farming methods on small-holder farms. We purchase green beans directly from subsistence farming communities at above international fair-trade prices, and then roast locally.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/cornerstorenetwork/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/cornerstorenetwork/', 'Email': 'mailto:info@cornerstorenetwork.org.au', 'Website': 'https://cornerstorenetwork.org.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Minimum Wines: Cultivating Joy, Sustainability, and Social Impact"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Minimum Wines contribute to regenerative social and environmental outcomes beyond just producing wine?
2. What percentage of Minimum Wines' revenue is dedicated to eco-social initiatives, tree planting, and paying rent to First Nations organizations?
3. What certifications and practices does Minimum Wines adhere to in order to maintain their commitment to organic, vegan, and net carbon neutral production?

__data__.text:
Minimum is a project of joy and love in making wine, sharing wine and connecting to the lands that ground it all. We are committed to creating quality organic wines, always seeking our own "minimum" - the fine balance of doing just enough, not too much, in the vineyard and winery. We commit ourselves, beyond wine, to contribute to regenerative social and environmental outcomes, activating artists and marginal voices where possible.
We are certified Organic, Vegan and Net Carbon Neutral, and are a very proud certified B Corp. Each year we give at least 5% of our revenue to a number of self-led projects that uplift our collective communities and ecosystems.
Wine is made from grapes; we make wine.5% To Impact: Each year, we give at least 5% of our revenue to eco-social initiatives (in 2022, we gave over 8%). This includes tree planting and rent payments and also includes funding a number of artistic projects, an annual exhibition, donations and staff wellness and emotional/cultural development.
1% of our revenue goes to planting trees: We work with One Tree Planted, where we self-select a number of tree-planting projects each year around the world that achieve a diverse set of ecological, social and political outcomes
1% of our revenue to paying the rent: We split our rent payments to three First Nations organisations: Paying The Rent, Djirra and Yorta Yorta National Aboriginal Corporation. Always was, always will be, Aboriginal land.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/minimumwines/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/minimumwines', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@minimumwines.com', 'Website': 'https://www.minimumwines.com/'}

metadata.document_title: "Alphington Farmers Market: Promoting Local, Sustainable, and Community-Focused Agriculture"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. What are the specific products available for purchase at the Alphington Farmers Market, and what sustainable practices are implemented at the market to reduce waste?
2. How does the Alphington Farmers Market contribute to promoting local agriculture, supporting producers, and fostering relationships between consumers and producers in the Victorian food industry?
3. How does the Alphington Farmers Market operate as a not-for-profit social enterprise, and how do donations from visitors contribute to the market's sustainability and other social enterprise initiatives?

__data__.text:
Alphington Farmers Market is held every Sunday from 9am to 1pm on the grounds of the Alphington Community Food Hub and the Melbourne Farmers Market HQ. Every Sunday, come shop for local fresh fruit and vegetables, free-range eggs and meats, olives and oil, honey, nuts and grains, dairy and cheeses, breads and pastries, and a wide array of locally made food products.
There’s coffee, fresh seasonal juice and loads for brekkie, along with ready-to-eat takeaway meals for lunch. The Wash Against Waste on-site wash-up station eliminates single-use disposable items, and Alphington FM is proudly plastic bag free, so don’t forget to BYO - including your coffee cup!
Entry is by voluntary donation - card only. As MFM is a not-for-profit social enterprise, all donations go back into the running of the market and our other social enterprise initiatives. Thank you!
Alphington Farmers Market runs every Sunday from 9am - 1pm.Alphington Farmers Market is part of Melbourne Farmers Markets (MFM). MFM is a registered not-for-profit and certified social enterprise dedicated to Victorian food and producers, regional food cultures, seasonal produce, biodiversity, sustainable farming practices and strengthening relationships between the consumer and the producer.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/melbournefarmersmarkets/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/MelbourneFarmersMarkets', 'Email': 'mailto:info@mfm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://melbourne-farmers-markets-mfm.myshopify.com/pages/alphington-farmers-market'}

metadata.document_title: "Cultivating Community: The Coburg Farmers Market's Commitment to Local Produce and Sustainability"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. What are the specific products available at Coburg Farmers Market in Brisbane, Australia, and how does the market support local producers and sustainable farming practices?
2. How does Coburg Farmers Market differentiate itself by offering visitors the opportunity to interact with chickens, explore composting setups, and enjoy live music on site?
3. In what ways does Coburg Farmers Market contribute to the community and promote environmental consciousness through initiatives such as being plastic bag free and operating on voluntary donations?

__data__.text:
Coburg Farmers Market is held on the grounds of the beautiful Coburg Primary School every Saturday from 8am to 1pm.
Every Saturday, come shop for local fresh fruit and vegetables, free-range eggs and meats, olives and oil, honey, nuts and grains, dairy and cheeses, bread and pastries, and a wide array of locally made food products.
In addition to the wonderful array of 30+ Victorian producers and small food businesses that attend each week, Coburg Primary School offers the chance for visitors to meet the chickens (who live in the 'Chicken Wing'), see the great composting set up, discover the herbs and veggies grown on the grounds, and play the piano that is permanently set up on the stage! Children and well-behaved dogs on leads will have a great time at Coburg Farmers Market!
This market embodies a vibrant community spirit and welcomes visitors from near and far. Coburg FM is plastic bag free, so please BYO reusable bags and coffee cups.
Entry is by voluntary donation - card only. As MFM is a not-for-profit social enterprise, all donations go back into the running of the market and our other social enterprise initiatives. Thank you!
Coburg Farmers Market runs every Saturday from 8am - 1pm.Coburg Farmers Market is part of Melbourne Farmers Markets (MFM). MFM is a registered not-for-profit and certified social enterprise dedicated to Victorian food and producers, regional food cultures, seasonal produce, biodiversity, sustainable farming practices and strengthening relationships between the consumer and the producer.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/melbournefarmersmarkets/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/MelbourneFarmersMarkets', 'Email': 'mailto:info@mfm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://melbourne-farmers-markets-mfm.myshopify.com/pages/coburg-farmers-market'}

metadata.document_title: "ORICoop: Empowering Sustainable Growth in Australia's Organic and Regenerative Farming Sector"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How is the Organic & Regenerative Investment Cooperative (ORICoop) working to empower sustainable growth in Australia's organic and regenerative farming sector?
2. What are the key areas ORICoop is currently focusing on, such as the ORCA grain project and building out investment pathways for organic enterprises?
3. How does ORICoop aim to connect and empower organic businesses, farmers, stakeholders, and investors in order to champion best practices and sustainable growth in the industry?

__data__.text:
Organic and Regenerative Investment Cooperative (ORICoop) aims to change the way we connect with food, farms, and people. We are dedicated to enabling investment & sustainable growth opportunities across the organic, regenerative, and biodynamic farming and food sectors in Australia. This entails acquiring, managing, and preserving organic and regenerative assets while championing best practices in the industry.
We place great importance on cultivating robust networks among our valued ORICoop members, farmers, stakeholders, and investors, as they play a pivotal role in the cooperative's future expansion. Our goal is to encourage sustainable and equitable investments that contribute to the advancement of environmental stewardship throughout Australia.ORICoop is working in 4 keys areas currently —
ORCA grain project - enabling and building out grain capacity for organic grain growers ad businesses in Australia
ORICoop network - connecting and empowering organic businesses in building resilient and strong organic enterprises
Advocating for organic businesses across the sector
Building out our investment pathway to provide aligned capital to underpin the sustainable growth of organic enterprises[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/organicinvestmentcooperative/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/ORICooperative', 'Email': 'mailto:carolyn@organicinvestmentcooperative.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.organicinvestmentcooperative.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Connecting Responsibly: REAL Pizza Pasta Salads & The Place of Wonder - A Comprehensive Guide to Responsible Eating and Sustainable Dining"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does REAL Pizza Pasta Salads connect responsibly with food, community, and the environment in Brisbane, Australia?
2. What initiatives does REAL Pizza Pasta Salads undertake during the day to promote community wellbeing and responsible eating?
3. How does The Place of Wonder contribute to REAL Pizza Pasta Salads' commitment to sourcing seasonal, local ingredients and promoting environmental awareness in the community?

__data__.text:
REAL Pizza Pasta Salads is a restaurant connecting responsibly with food, community & the environment. By day, REAL hosts producer markets, food swap events, community wellbeing workshops and more. We also provide our restaurant facility for community fundraising opportunities.
At night, our seasonal restaurant is open for dine-in and takeaway. We're passionate about helping inform you about your food choices and putting eating responsibility at the forefront of what we do. We limit packaging, minimise and repurpose waste, and source seasonal and local ingredients. We work closely with a range of regional suppliers and The Place of Wonder's garden to offer a seasonal, fresh and unique selection of ingredients for you to choose from.
The Place of Wonder is a 3-acre, edible habitat on Port Campbell's outskirts that helps supply seasonal produce to REAL Pizza Pasta Salads. Additionally, it is a place of learning and living, hosting edible gardening workshops, occasional garden tours and fresh produce tastings.Seasonal producer markets to promote awareness of alternative access to ingredients.
Community fundraising opportunities to build individual skills and support community initiatives.
Community wellbeing workshops such as yoga and sound therapy.
Food swap events.
At REAL & The Place of Wonder, we know that everything is linked, and as such, we are responsible to all. This belief motivates us to inspire, support and sustain environmental awareness in our community and, where appropriate, support change, building individual capacity and enhancing diversity.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/realpizzapastasalads/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/REALpizzapastasalads', 'Email': 'mailto:info@theplaceofwonder.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.realpizzapastasalads.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Carlton Farmers Market: Promoting Local Producers, Sustainable Practices, and Community Engagement"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. What are the specific types of products available at Carlton Farmers Market, and how do they contribute to promoting local producers and sustainable practices?
2. How does Carlton Farmers Market encourage visitors to make a positive impact on the local food system and environment through their market practices?
3. How does the voluntary donation system at Carlton Farmers Market support the market's operation as a not-for-profit social enterprise and contribute to other social enterprise initiatives?

__data__.text:
Carlton Farmers Market is held on the grounds of the gorgeous Carlton North Primary School every Saturday from 8am - 1pm. The School offers a great playground and open spaces for the kids, plus outdoor seating to relax and enjoy the market fare.
Carlton locals, and those from further afield, enjoy access to the finest seasonal Victorian fruit, veg, free range eggs and meats, olives and oil, honey, nuts and grains, dairy and cheeses, bread and pastries. All this, and only a 10-minute drive from Melbourne's CBD!
Bring your own coffee mug and reusable bags to the market, and make a positive impact on our local food system and the environment.
Entry is by voluntary donation - card only. As MFM is a not-for-profit social enterprise, all donations go back into the running of the market and our other social enterprise initiatives. Thank you!
Carlton Farmers Market runs every Saturday from 8am - 1pm.
The market entrance is on O'Grady Street.Carlton Farmers Market is part of Melbourne Farmers Markets (MFM). MFM is a registered not-for-profit and certified social enterprise dedicated to Victorian food and producers, regional food cultures, seasonal produce, biodiversity, sustainable farming practices and strengthening relationships between the consumer and the producer.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/melbournefarmersmarkets/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/MelbourneFarmersMarkets', 'Email': 'mailto:info@mfm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://melbourne-farmers-markets-mfm.myshopify.com/pages/carlton-farmers-market'}

metadata.document_title: "Towards a Sustainable and Inclusive Victorian Food System: A Blueprint for Collaboration and Innovation"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How many projects has Moving Feast undertaken since 2020 and what is the total amount of support they have received from government, philanthropy, and industry?
2. What are the key partners leading network actions with Moving Feast and what types of collaborations do these projects involve?
3. What specific projects are included in the Purpose Precinct initiative at Melbourne's Queen Victoria Market and how do they contribute to growing the social enterprise sector and facilitating food system experimentation?

__data__.text:
Moving Feast is a network of social innovators collaborating for a connected, fair and regenerative Victorian food system. Projects align with five ‘Challenges’ with big, audacious goals for change: Open & optimised collaboration, Reimagining food futures, Clean & green food economies, Diverse & inclusive jobs, and Net zero food. ‘Challenges’ are being progressively iterated through co-creation with community and food system stakeholders to ensure inclusive representation and to build new networks for action.
Moving Feast have undertaken 30 projects since 2020 enabled by AU$15M of government, philanthropy, and industry support.
Partners leading network actions currently include CERES, Collingwood Children’s Farm, Common Ground Project, Community Grocer, Cultivating Community, Melbourne Farmers Markets, Open Food Network, and STREAT. Projects involve collaborations between diverse actors, including social enterprise, government, community, and industry.
Expressions of interest in project collaborations are welcomed.Purpose Precinct: A place-based social enterprise precinct at Melbourne’s Queen Victoria Market designed to grow the sector and facilitate food system experimentation. Projects include circular innovation to reduce QVM food waste, new job pathways into waste capture and food preservation, food tourism experiences, and shared facilities for developing circular products and foodie businesses. See: https://bit.ly/40YxscM.
Open Sauce: A two-year circular economy project in working across our collective organisations to rescue off-cuts, excess produce from farmers, and other waste items from our kitchens, farms and offices, and turn them into beautiful, circular-economy retail products.
Green Job Pathways: CERES, Collingwood Children’s Farm, Melbourne Farmers Market and STREAT creating new pathways for young people into urban farming.[]{'Instagram': 'http://instagram.com/movingfeastvic', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/movingfeastvic', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@movingfeast.net', 'Website': 'https://movingfeast.net/'}

metadata.document_title: Empowering Young People Through Food: STREAT's Social Enterprise Initiatives and Programs
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does STREAT support young people in Melbourne through their various food businesses and programs?
2. What are the key focus areas of STREAT's social enterprise initiatives and programs?
3. How does STREAT contribute to the development of the social enterprise sector in Melbourne, particularly through initiatives like the Purpose Precinct and Moving Feast?

__data__.text:
STREAT is a registered charity and leading social enterprise with over a decade of experience supporting young people across Melbourne. Our purpose is to help young people thrive and belong with a healthy self, home and work. We have a portfolio of food businesses, including cafes, kiosks, an artisan bakery, a coffee roastery, and a catering and events company. All of our business profits are re-invested into providing holistic support and training pathways for vulnerable young people.
Our four portfolio focus areas are:
People: Providing supported employment pathways into the food system for marginalised young Victorians and superpowering organisations who work with young people
Places: Designing and building vibrant and youthful places.
Planet: Being industry leaders in regenerating the planet
through conserving and regenerating energy,
water, soil & biodiversity
Performance: Building a sustainable social enterprise
business engine, and collaborating for systems change.STREAT has various programs available to young people to find employment pathways into the food industry, including a half-day Taste of STREAT workshop, an eight-week Fast-Track To Work program, and a nine-month Paid To Work program.
STREAT are co-leads of the Purpose Precinct (https://bit.ly/40YxscM), a place-based, social and circular hub at Melbourne’s Queen Victoria Market designed to grow the visibility and impact of the social enterprise sector, develop new foodie social enterprises and circular products, create inclusive job pathways, and expand participation cross sectors and communities, anchored in the food system.
STREAT are also co-leads of Moving Feast (https://movingfeast.net/), a network of social innovators collaborating for a connected, fair and regenerative Victorian food system, who are conducting projects at the Purpose Precinct.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/streatmelbourne/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/streatmelbourne', 'Email': 'mailto:info@streat.com.au', 'Website': 'https://streat.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Sustainable Farming Initiatives in Northern Rivers NSW: Regenerative Practices, Closed-Loop System, Carbon Sequestration, and Collaboration for a Healthier Future"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Woodland Valley Farm promote sustainable food production for a healthier future through regenerative practices and a closed-loop system?
2. What initiatives is Woodland Valley Farm involved in to decrease the release of greenhouse gases, enhance soil health, and generate nutrient-dense, sustainable food on a commercial scale?
3. How does Woodland Valley Farm collaborate with organizations like Landcare Australia and the CSIRO to establish farming and food systems that support the planet and population into the future, particularly in the Northern Rivers NSW region?

__data__.text:
Woodland Valley Farm is a vertically integrated regenerative farming model that promotes sustainable food production for a healthier future. Our core business revolves around sustainable food production, with a strong focus on land regeneration, carbon farming, and fostering biodiversity within the environment. By implementing regenerative practices, we effectively decrease the release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, enhance soil health, and generate nutrient-dense, sustainable food on a commercial scale.
The farm produces pasture-raised hen and duck eggs, pasture-raised beef and regeneratively farmed vegetables, herbs, and fruits, which are used in the manufacture of nutritious and sustainable foods. We operate a closed-loop system from farm to food production.
The farm produces pasture-raised hen and duck eggs, pasture-raised beef, and regeneratively farmed vegetables, herbs, and fruits used to manufacture nutritious and sustainable foods. We operate a closed-loop system from farm to food production.
Building life back into the soil improves yields and produce quality and allows us to care for more livestock, resulting in increased productivity and a compelling endorsement for regenerative farming.
We are focused on and committed to minimal inputs and minimal waste in all activities. We operate an entirely off-grid farm with high solar capability and rainwater catchment. Our quest is to have the tightest, most sustainable loop in all that we do.We are one of two farms in the Northern Rivers NSW to team with Landcare Australia in a 2-year project to understand the benefits of multi-species cover crops and how and when to plant crops for the best results. The CSIRO is conducting similar testing as we work to establish farming and food systems that support our planet and population into the future.
We are also partaking in the Emissions Reduction Fund project to sequester carbon from the atmosphere, to support the government's net zero emissions target by 2050.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/woodlandvalleyfarm/?hl=en', 'Facebook':

metadata.document_title: Cultivating Regenerative Solutions for a Sustainable Future: A Comprehensive Guide
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Sustainable Table contribute to regenerating Australia's farming, food, and fibre systems?
2. What kind of support does Sustainable Table provide to change makers and regenerative projects in Australia?
3. How does Sustainable Table collaborate with industry stakeholders to promote a regenerative, ecological future in Australia?

__data__.text:
At Sustainable Table, we are regenerating Australia’s farming, food and fibre systems from the ground up.
Change makers all over Australia are working on regenerative solutions to the climate crisis and the social and environmental problems our farming, food and fibre systems face. These solutions are grounded in care for people and planet. Sustainable Table exists to fund these change makers, share their stories and cultivate regeneration.We connect regenerative projects and change makers with philanthropic funds and aligned impact investors.
We develop and nurture regenerative industry networks, knowledge and capacity through targeted support.
We collaborate with industry stakeholders to amplify and share stories for a thriving, regenerative, ecological future.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/sustainable.table/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/thesustainabletable/', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@sustainabletable.org.au', 'Website': 'https://www.sustainabletable.org.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "The Farm at Byron Bay: A Comprehensive Guide to Sustainable Farming, Community Engagement, and Educational Initiatives"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. What is the motto of The Farm at Byron Bay and how does it inspire their activities and engagement with the community?
2. What types of animals can be found on The Farm's fields and how are they utilized in the on-site restaurant, cafe, and produce store?
3. How does The Farm at Byron Bay differentiate itself from other farms by emphasizing traditional, sustainable methods that are 100% spray and chemical free?

__data__.text:
The Farm is principally a working farm, housing a collection of micro-businesses all sharing in a common goal. Our motto, 'Grow, Feed, Educate', inspires all that we do here and for the community at large. We offer a platform for community experience seeing how food is grown and produced, sprouting a curiosity and desire to learn more.Our 80 acre working farm is home to a community of growers, producers, eateries, and educators who share a passion for growing food using traditional, sustainable methods that are 100% spray and chemical free.
The Farm’s fields are also home to heritage-breed pigs, heritage Scottish Highland cattle and chickens, all of which roam freely and are used for meat and eggs in the on-site restaurant, cafe and produce store. A short stroll will see you stumble across fields of flowers and row upon row of lush greens and vegetables, also used and sold on-site.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'http://instagram.com/thefarmatbyronbay', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/thefarmbyronbay', 'Email': 'mailto:info@thefarm.com.au', 'Website': 'https://thefarm.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Empowering Social Enterprises and Food Innovation at QVM's Purpose Precinct: Creating a Regenerative Food System"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How many social enterprises currently retail their products at the Purpose Precinct at Queen Victoria Market, and what is the goal for the number of enterprises by 2024?
2. How much organic food waste from Queen Victoria Market is annually composted, and what products will be created from this waste through the development of a shared preserving kitchen and retail pantry?
3. How many new jobs will be created over the next two years through the development of new food infrastructure at the Purpose Precinct, and what types of employment pathways will be available in waste capture, food preserving, retail, and transport and logistics?

__data__.text:
The Purpose Precinct at Queen Victoria Market (QVM) is a ‘social and circular’ front door to Victoria’s social enterprises. The Precinct currently retails wares of 25+ social enterprises, with the aim to double that by 2024. The Precinct will also create employment pathways for priority jobseekers who face barriers to employment.
QVM is Victoria’s leading food destination, with 10+ million people visiting it each year. With such a strong connection to multiple points of the food system, including supply chains, retail and food waste, the Precinct is an ideal site for food system experimentation. The Precinct is soon to house shared infrastructure for Moving Feast, a network of social innovators collaborating to build a connected, fair and regenerative Victorian food system. The Precinct and Moving Feast share objectives for activating people and places for regenerative food futures.Circular innovation: Annually, over 960+ tonnes of QVM’s organic food waste goes into composting. With the development of a shared preserving kitchen and retail pantry, food waste will be captured and turned into chutneys, sauces, jams, dried fruits and dried herbs and spices.
Green jobs: The new food infrastructure will create new employment pathways into waste capture, food preserving, retail and transport and logistics. Over 75 jobs will be created over the coming two years.
Food tourism and experiences: Work is underway to develop some new food trails starting at QVM, encouraging people to explore the incredible things that regional food social enterprises have to offer.
Participation and collaboration: The site offers a real opportunity for people to come and roll up their sleeves, put on an apron, learn and share. E-learning modules will also be developed to help would-be food innovators test and create new retail-ready circular products.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/purposeprecinct/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/purposeprecinct/', 'Email':

metadata.document_title: "Regrarians Ltd.: Pioneering Regenerative Agroecological Landscape and Enterprise Planning"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:

2. What is the significance of the 10-layer 'Regrarians Platform®' in the field of agroecological landscape and enterprise planning, and how has it been utilized by agricultural enterprises in over 80 countries?
3. In what ways does Regrarians Ltd. differentiate itself as the world's leading training provider of regenerative agroecological landscape and enterprise planning, and how has its approach impacted the agricultural industry in Australia and beyond?

__data__.text: Regrarians Ltd. is an Australian-based non-profit that is the world's leading training provider of regenerative agroecological landscape and enterprise planning. Since 1993 Regrarians has worked with many 1000's of agricultural enterprises in over 80 countries, and since 2004 has introduced 'regenerative agriculture' to over 20 countries across the world.Central to the work of the Regrarians® is the 10-layer 'Regrarians Platform®' —this is globally recognised as the most comprehensive agroecological landscape and enterprise planning framework. Training around the use of the Regrarians Platform is through Regrarians' longitudinal REX® online and onsite farm planning courses and the Regrarians® Workplace professional development and liaison network.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/regrarians/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/Regrarians/', 'Email': 'mailto:info@regrarians.org', 'Website': 'http://www.regrarians.org/'}

metadata.document_title: Sustainable Farming and Conservation Practices at Moyarra Pastoral Company
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Moyarra Pastoral Company implement regenerative grazing management to maintain perennial pastures with 100% groundcover and long rest times?
2. What specific landcare projects has Moyarra Pastoral Company undertaken to protect the endangered Giant Gippsland Earthworm and waterways on their farm?
3. How does Moyarra Pastoral Company collaborate with an organic CSA butcher for meat sales, and what benefits does this partnership provide for sustainable farming practices?

__data__.text:
Moyarra Pastoral Company is an 80-hectare, certified organic farm grazing lamb and beef in the hills of South Gippsland. The Brandon family are committed to farming in harmony with the ecosystem, applying regenerative grazing management to maintain perennial pastures with 100% groundcover and long rest times. Over 20% of the land is re-vegetated to indigenous forest, where the endangered Giant Gippsland Earthworm and waterways are protected.Landcare projects; side-by-side soil testing to compare regenerative with conventional management.
Giant Gippsland Earthworm study.
Accounting For Nature's natural capital account to measure environmental and productive conditions.
Collaborating with an organic CSA butcher for meat sales.['Ecological Practices (certifications)', 'Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/moyarrapastoral/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/moyarrapastoral', 'Email': 'mailto:baabrandon@gmail.com'}

metadata.document_title: "Building a Sustainable and Inclusive City-Region Food System: The Role of Community Food Resilience Centers (CRFC)"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does the Canberra Region Food Collaborative (CRFC) contribute to ensuring food security, resilience, economic diversity, emissions reduction, and inclusion objectives in Canberra?
2. What role does the CRFC play in assisting the ACT Government in implementing its Food Strategy and ensuring the importance of food in achieving the ACT's wellbeing objectives?
3. How does the CRFC support the establishment of an integrated City-Region food system for Canberra, the ACT, and the surrounding region, while also serving as a blueprint for a national program supporting local and city-region food systems?

__data__.text:
The CRFC is an independent NFP broker in the local food system, working to ensure Canberra’s food security, resilience, economic diversity, emissions and inclusion objectives.
It seeks to assist the ACT Government implement its Food Strategy and ensure the importance of food is recognised in the achievement of the ACT's wellbeing objectives.
The CRFC provides an organising principle for establishing an integrated City-Region food system for Canberra, the ACT and surrounding region. It also presents a blue-print for a national proorgam supporting local and city-region food systems.
The CRFC does not produce, transport or sell food. It assists enterprises, through ‘soft infrastructure’ throughout the supply chain to do so. It focuses on food produced in or within 250 kms of the city and encourages the sourcing of food from further afield produced with sustainable practices.
These enterprises span the full gamut of stakeholder groups including:
• Individual food and beverage businesses such as farmers and manufacturers
• Food cooperatives, farmers markets, food service and institutional care providers
• Service providers such as retailers, e-commerce platforms, training providers, providores, researchers, schools, technology providers and transport & logistics entities.
• Social enterprises engaged with the food system to further sustainability and inclusive objectives including food relief; nutrition; food waste and ethical production practicesIndependent broker for food system connectivity and business-to-business & business-to-community.
Mobile food labour pool - an innovative approach that will help guarantee enough skilled workers inside and near the city for most agrifood enterprises.
Food in the Capital Events program - incl Australia's only national conference dedicated to establishing integrated City-Region Food systems.
Coordination of 72 food stakeholder groups helping shape the development of our city's food future.
Sustainable Food Investment projects attraction and facilitation - $350 million pipeline.[]{'Email': 'mailto:michael.claessens@rdaact.org.au', 'Website': 'https://www.agrifood-hub.com/'}

metadata.document_title: Regenerative Farming for Biodiversity and Soil Health: Sustainable Practices and Environmental Restoration at Brooklands Free Range Farms
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Brooklands Free Range Farms been implementing regenerative farming practices to improve soil health and biodiversity on Dja Dja Wurrung country since 2012?
2. What role do rare breeds, such as 100% Grass Fed British White Beef and Pastured Whey Fed Berkshire Pork, play in building healthy soils at Brooklands Free Range Farms?
3. How has Brooklands Free Range Farms been collaborating with organizations like the North Central Catchment Management Authority and Central Victorian Regenerative Farmers Group to conduct Cover Crop trials and improve soil organic carbon levels on their farm?

__data__.text:
Regeneratively farming on Dja Dja Wurrung country since 2012 with a focus on biodiversity within our soils (we like to call our soil army) and our whole environment. Concentrating on rare breeds for their inherent ability to forage and resistance under all conditions. We breed and raise 100 % Grass Fed British White Beef, Pastured Whey Fed Berkshire Pork which all play an important role in building our healthy soils through our developed grazing systems and their natural fertilization. We move our stock frequently and sow up to 15 species of forage crops for the pigs for their "Salad Bar" grazing. Cattle grazing areas are encouraging native pastures to return. All our produce is born and raised on the farm here at Brookland.

We sell at Farmer's Markets in Daylesford, Trentham, Ballan, Alphington & Abbotsford, with a Farmgate opening soon. Also available at times are our 10kg mixed boxes.
We supply local restaurants, including Lake House Daylesford & Du Fermier in Trentham.
We also have the odd farm tour and like to help others starting the regenerative journey, so keep an eye on the socials!Cover Crop Trials — We are at the tail end of our regenerative farming soil improvement Cover Crop trials that have been ongoing for the last 5 years with North Central Catchment Management Authority & Central Victorian Regenerative Farmers Group. The last part is using the the pigs to eradicate the onion weed and further soil improvements through moving pigs. Currently, Organic Carbon in the trial area sits between 6-8% (started at 2.5%).
Fencing — Another project that was self-funded and recently completed was fencing off one of the dams and devising an "around the dam" grazing system with water points.
Native Tree Planting & Perennials — From Autumn til Winter (2023), we are hoping to have some tree planting days

metadata.document_title: Regenerative Farming for Biodiversity and Soil Health: Sustainable Practices and Environmental Restoration at Brooklands Free Range Farms
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has Brooklands Free Range Farms been collaborating with local organizations and groups to implement regenerative farming practices over the past 5 years?
2. What specific sustainable practices has Brooklands Free Range Farms implemented, such as using pigs to eradicate onion weed and improving soil health through movement?
3. What future projects does Brooklands Free Range Farms have in store, such as native tree planting, eradicating blackberries, and incorporating more native grasses into their grazing system, and how do they plan to execute these projects?

__data__.text:
been ongoing for the last 5 years with North Central Catchment Management Authority & Central Victorian Regenerative Farmers Group. The last part is using the the pigs to eradicate the onion weed and further soil improvements through moving pigs. Currently, Organic Carbon in the trial area sits between 6-8% (started at 2.5%).
Fencing — Another project that was self-funded and recently completed was fencing off one of the dams and devising an "around the dam" grazing system with water points.
Native Tree Planting & Perennials — From Autumn til Winter (2023), we are hoping to have some tree planting days in the back spring paddock, as well as look into incorporating more native grasses into our grazing system, with some native grasses starting to appear from grazing, some of the volcanic areas seem to have lost their seed bank. We have already purchased over 100 trees, and the first lot will go in with the help of Wesley College School (Y9) in Term 2. We are keen to incorporate more native grasses, but the high costs combined with our limited expertise in this area means progress is slower than we would like, and we could expedite this with funding support.
A big future project will be eradicating blackberries from our creek and planting accordingly to prevent soil erosion and maybe get neighbours on board too.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/brooklandsfreerangefarms/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/BrooklandsFreeRangeFarms', 'Email': 'mailto:farmers@brooklandsfarms.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.brooklandsfarms.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Empowering Community Through Regenerative Farming Practices and Improved Food Access Initiatives"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Common Ground Project empower the community through regenerative farming practices and improved food access initiatives?
2. What partnerships and programs has Common Ground Project established to support food security in the region and create fairer access to locally grown, healthy food?
3. In what ways is Common Ground Project expanding its farm and program offerings to further support training and employment pathways for individuals facing disadvantages in the Geelong region?

__data__.text:
Common Ground Project is a regenerative farm, food hub and social enterprise that connects, educates and empowers the community through food and farming. We exist to cultivate a stronger, fairer, more resilient food system and empower agency and access for those who need it most.
We do this by offering training and employment pathways to people facing structural barriers to employment and by providing an inclusive space for growing, cooking, purchasing, knowledge sharing, and ongoing community collaboration. All our programs support food security in the region, as we work to create fairer access to locally grown, healthy food.
Grounded in regenerative farming, and in recognition of the urgent need for a more resilient food system, we believe that connection to land, food, work and community can drive real, meaningful social and environmental change.We are in the ongoing process of expanding our farm to grow more food for the region. Increasing soil health and biodiversity is at the core of all our programs.
We have partnered with VicHealth as a Future Healthy Food Hub, aiming to connect the community to local producers as well as educate and supply the community with produce from our farm. Our permanent farmgate market will be complemented by programs, events and seminars focusing on food and farming systems.
We are also expanding our Staying Grounded program, which provides training and employment pathways in farming and hospitality for people facing disadvantages in the Geelong region.
We are developing a preserving and pickling program where excess produce can be made into products sold in our Food Hub.
We are also refining our broader program offering, including school programs, school holiday programs, workshops, volunteering programs and hosting collaborations with local organisations.['Regenerative Practices']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/common_ground_project/', 'Facebook': 'https://www.facebook.com/commongroundprojectaustralia', 'Email': 'mailto:foodhub@commongroundproject.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.instagram.com/common_ground_project/'}

metadata.document_title: Empowering Producers Through Regenerative Agriculture and Education: A Comprehensive Guide
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How has RCS evolved over the past 30 years to become Australia's leading private provider of education and advisory services in regenerative agriculture?
2. What specific programs and workshops does RCS offer to empower producers in improving their bottom line and regenerating landscapes?
3. How does RCS support producers in rural and regional Australia beyond initial in-person training, and what sets their learning pathway apart as a benchmark for capacity building in the industry?

__data__.text:
At RCS, we empower producers to increase their bottom line, whilst regenerating landscapes, and growing natural capital.
Our knowledge, both time-tested and leading edge, is gleaned from over 30 years of listening, observation and science. We walk alongside those on a regenerative journey, and step farmers through proven methods and practical tools that build upon existing skills and knowledge.
Our commitment to this approach extends back to the 1980s when co-founder Dr Terry McCosker began exploring ways to help Australian producers find a better way. Since then, we’ve grown to become Australia’s leading private provider of education and advisory services to the regenerative agriculture industry.
With this support, those on the land can achieve clearly defined goals that enrich business, wellbeing, family, community, and the Australian landscape in which we live and work.RCS has developed a learning pathway that has been refined over more than thirty years through research and development to become the benchmark for capacity building in rural and regional Australia. Our training programs have been designed to build on producers’ existing knowledge and to provide support long after the initial in-person training. Learning continues back on-farm with consultant visits and an extensive offering of follow-up programs and short courses.
Our Core Programs include:
The Farming&GrazingforProfit™ School
This is a seven-day workshop to introduce you to the RCS principles that cover business, production, land and people.
ExecuLinktive®
Membership to a network of like-minded and motivated producers who meet three times a year at facilitated meetings. It will support you in making hard decisions within your business and keep you accountable.[]{'Instagram': 'http://www.instagram.com/rcs_team/', 'Facebook': 'http://www.facebook.com/RCSAustralia', 'Email': 'mailto:info@rcsaustralia.com.au', 'Website': 'http://www.rcsaustralia.com.au/'}

__data__.text: We are a farm gate selling produce grown on site (by Five Tales Farm) along with grass-fed Belted Galloway beef and free-range Dorset Down lamb grown on our other property down the road. Over a 12-month growing season, we also source locally grown produce from approximately 70 Mornington Peninsula farms. We also value-add our produce into pickles, preserves and take-home meals.Our farm gate is open 7 days a week, 8am - 6pm. We are establishing a wholesale side to our business supplying hospitality businesses with local produce. We also run workshops on the farm, teaching people about growing and cooking local food. We currently lease approximately 5 acres to Five Tales Farm and hope to make more of our land available to other young farmers.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/torellofarm/', 'Facebook': 'http://www.facebook.com/torellofarm', 'Email': 'mailto:info@torellofarm.com.au', 'Website': 'http://www.torellofarm.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Uncommon Folk: Pioneering Regenerative Farming and Community Connection"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Uncommon Folk aim to empower, educate, and reconnect people to food production through their practice of regenerative agriculture?
2. What are the key projects that Uncommon Folk is focusing on this year, including building a farming collective, establishing a farm gate as a community hub, and starting an education program for students and the community?
3. In what ways does Uncommon Folk plan to share their learnings and practices of regenerative farming with other landowners looking for a productive, equitable, and restorative land use model for their farms?

__data__.text: Our vision is to pioneer the future of small-scale farming as a collective of profitable, regenerative farming enterprises who work together and connect with community, to build a strong and thriving local food system. Through our experience, and the expertise of our collective community we aim to empower, educate and reconnect people to food production. Through our practice of regenerative agriculture, we will restore the land, improve biodiversity, and have a positive environmental impact, and we will share our learnings with other landowners looking for a productive, equitable and restorative land use model for their farm.Our key projects this year are to build our farming collective and our farm gate as a community hub, to start our education program to engage students and the community in food and farming practices, and to baseline measure and establish strong regenerative farming practices.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/_uncommon_folk/', 'Email': 'mailto:hello@uncommonfolk.com.au', 'Website': 'https://www.uncommonfolk.com.au/'}

metadata.document_title: "Building Resilient and Regenerative Food Systems: Open Food Network's Strategic Objectives and Projects"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How is Open Food Network Australia working towards building resilient and regenerative food systems?
2. What are the specific projects and strategic objectives of Open Food Network Australia for the years 2022-2025?
3. How does Open Food Network Australia collaborate with other organizations and stakeholders to achieve its vision of fair, open food and farming networks?

__data__.text:
Open Food Network (OFN) has been building better food systems since 2012. Our vision is for a world where fair, open food & farming networks (re)connect people and regenerate the earth. We:
make regenerative food more accessible through open and shared digital infrastructure for food supply networks; and
co-create and activate short food supply chains to enable resilient community food systems.
We are open source & non-profit - everything we do is available for use & adaptation.

Our 2022-2025 Strategic Objectives:
Demonstrating systems change: We harness people, technology and expertise to deliver powerful products, projects and services that transform food systems.
Creating an enabling environment: We influence and set the agenda for future investment in food systems by fostering strategic partnerships and long-term relationships which unlock funding.
Building an inspiring organisation: We maximise the capacity of our people and business to effect positive change in Australia and as part of the Global Commons.Open Food Network Platform and technical services: we make regenerative food more accessible through open and shared digital infrastructure for food supply networks
Food with Dignity Project: in collaboration with two Victorian enterprises, Open Food Network will develop, test, and recommend system designs for improved ‘food with dignity’.
Merri-bek Food Leadership Action Group (FLAG) Project: a co-design multi-year ‘regional food activation’ project to establish a community food hub in Merri-bek.
Connecting the Tech: a project leading to the development of API endpoints to build immediate technical solutions for users.
Regenerative Produce Discovery Project: is aiming to increase demand and market access for Australian regenerative producers and products by making it easier for priority buyers to discover, understand and purchase from them.
Victorian Community Food Enterprise Rapid Needs and Value Assessment: Open Food Network will lead a ‘rapid needs and value assessment’ project for the sector to inform a collective bid for funding/support from government and philanthropy.['Funded by Sustainable Table']{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/openfoodnetworkaus/', 'Facebook':

metadata.document_title: "Future Seeds Nursery: Cultivating a Sustainable Future through Organic Seedlings and Community Engagement"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:
1. How does Future Seeds Nursery plan to support young farmers in gaining an equitable foothold as local food suppliers?
2. What specific sustainable practices does Future Seeds Nursery implement in their operations, such as the use of solar power and sensor-based irrigation systems?
3. In what ways does Future Seeds Nursery aim to contribute to the local organic and regenerative farming community in the Brisbane region?

__data__.text:
Future Seeds Nursery is a small-scale sustainable production nursery growing organic, culturally relevant herb, flower and vegetable seedlings for schools, farms, families and community groups.
Our mission is to support young farmers to gain an equitable foothold as local food suppliers by providing an outlet for affordable organically grown seedling stock, as well as enabling active knowledge and skill sharing across agricultural, community and training sectors.Over the next 6 months, Future Seeds Nursery plans to expand its operations on a site in Upper Pakenham. It will be at this location where Future Seeds can install a greenhouse, complete with solar power (to use for dynamic ventilation, heat mats and sensor-based irrigation systems), as well as a space to trial new crops to add to our knowledge base of the requirements and limitations of each crop throughout its life cycle (and beyond the nursery). In taking this next step, Future Seeds aspires to become a leading organic nursery to provide seedling stock for organic and regenerative farms in the local region.[]{'Instagram': 'https://www.instagram.com/futureseedsnursery/', 'Email': 'mailto:futureseedsnursery@gmail.com'}
